Failed to open Android NDK built binary due to SimProcedureError
body:
### Description

When openning a aarch64 binary, which is built with Android NDK, in Angr Management, the following error occured:
```
  File "D:\Workspace\angr_dev\angr\angr\sim_procedure.py", line 334, in static_exits
    raise SimProcedureError("static_exits() is not implemented for %s" % self)
angr.errors.SimProcedureError: static_exits() is not implemented for <SimProcedure __libc_init>
```

This is because `angr/procedures/glibc/__libc_init.py` set `ADDS_EXITS=True` but there's no implementation for `static_exits()`

### Steps to reproduce the bug

Open this and start analysis in AM:
[test_ndk.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/11228574/test_ndk.zip)


### Environment

_No response_

_No response_

body:
### Description

```
def subgraph_between_nodes(graph, source, frontier, include_frontier=False):
    """
    For a directed graph, return a subgraph that includes all nodes going from a source node to a target node.

    :param networkx.DiGraph graph:  The directed graph.
    :param source:                  The source node.
    :param list frontier:           A collection of target nodes.
    :param bool include_frontier:   Should nodes in frontier be included in the subgraph.
    :return:                        A subgraph.
    :rtype:                         networkx.DiGraph
    """

    graph = networkx.DiGraph(graph)  # make a copy
    for pred in list(graph.predecessors(source)):
        # make sure we cannot go from any other node to the source node
        graph.remove_edge(pred, source)

    g0 = networkx.DiGraph()

    if source not in graph or any(node not in graph for node in frontier):
        raise KeyError("Source node or frontier nodes are not in the source graph.")

    # BFS on graph and add new nodes to g0
    queue = [source]
    traversed = set()

    frontier = set(frontier)

    while queue:
        node = queue.pop(0)
        traversed.add(node)

        for _, succ, data in graph.out_edges(node, data=True):
            g0.add_edge(node, succ, **data)
            if succ in traversed or succ in frontier:
                continue
            for frontier_node in frontier:
                if networkx.has_path(graph, succ, frontier_node):
                    queue.append(succ)
                    break

    # recursively remove all nodes that have less than two neighbors
    to_remove = [
        n
        for n in g0.nodes()
        if n not in frontier and n is not source and (g0.out_degree[n] == 0 or g0.in_degree[n] == 0)
    ]
    while to_remove:
        g0.remove_nodes_from(to_remove)
        to_remove = [
            n
            for n in g0.nodes()
            if n not in frontier and n is not source and (g0.out_degree[n] == 0 or g0.in_degree[n] == 0)
        ]

    if not include_frontier:
        # remove the frontier nodes
        g0.remove_nodes_from(frontier)

    return g0
```
If don't skip g0.has_edge(node, succ), it will enter an infinite loop

### Steps to reproduce the bug
[归档.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/11068273/default.zip)



### Environment

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

title: Loading an angrdb is slow
body:
### Description

Loading an angrdb for a non-trivial binary can take upwards of **20 seconds**. Apparently most of the time is spent just re-lifting blocks to determine instruction addresses. We should either make node reconstruction lazier or cache the addresses to reduce this insane startup cost.

![load_db py-2023-03-01T17:25:25-07:00](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8210/222299428-a74c40ef-01bf-4c17-b41d-8d7350a68d6a.svg)

Ideally saving and loading the db would be near-instant, but we can at least fix loading to begin with.

### Steps to reproduce the bug

An example benchmark:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
import angr
from angr.angrdb import AngrDB
import os.path
import time

bin_path = '/usr/bin/qemu-mips'

time_start = time.time()
proj = angr.Project(bin_path, auto_load_libs=False)
proj.analyses.CFGFast(normalize=True)
time_end = time.time()
print(f'Creating project took {time_end - time_start:.3f} seconds')

db_path = os.path.basename(bin_path) + '.adb'
time_start = time.time()
angrdb = AngrDB(project=proj)
angrdb.dump(db_path, kbs=[proj.kb])
time_end = time.time()
print(f'Saving angrdb took {time_end - time_start:.3f} seconds')

time_start = time.time()
db = AngrDB()
db.load(db_path)
time_end = time.time()
print(f'Loading angrdb took {time_end - time_start:.3f} seconds')
```

```
Creating project took 66.311 seconds
Saving angrdb took 9.528 seconds
Loading angrdb took 24.057 seconds
```

### Environment

angr @ cb6f234a04b94e81954c74d79ce49c6711ea54b2

### Additional context

_No response_

body: CStructuredCodeGenerator._access() may end up in an infinite loop when it tries to access offset 0 of any single-field structs. This is because type negotiation converts the first field into the struct type itself. As a temporary fix, we disallow type negotiation to return struct types if the old type is not a struct type.

title: Decompilation error in ARM binary's thunk
body:
### Description

Context:

I wrote a program containing 100 calls to `gt32` for unit test:
```c
int32_t gt32(int32_t a, int32_t b){
	return a > b;
}

int main(){
	sink(gt32(3236716579, 3221347276));
	sink(gt32(1379110817, 1113518874));
	sink(gt32(896556042, 2704120162));
        ......
	sink(gt32(3002246636, 3351598752));
	sink(gt32(3890490740, 2816674071));
	sink(gt32(3626833283, 1567037049));
}
```
I compiled it using arm-linux-gnueabihf-gcc. Then I found gcc inserted a [thunk](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2641489/what-is-a-thunk) into the binary, and optimized the last call to `gt32` into a call to the thunk  `sub_401059`.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35004522/216891981-04d0e6d9-4933-471c-9256-37bb28ff28a1.png)

Following are some disassembly/decompilation results:

Disassembly result of the thunk (correct):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35004522/216888435-6c83e95c-9a5f-4079-8ad7-b7b9ed9bbede.png)
AIL representation (wrong):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35004522/216888480-bddd7315-e145-47b7-8854-28b229fd3513.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35004522/216888541-eff31d5a-f2f1-479e-af2b-9eb4c6a36690.png)
IDA Pro's pseudo code (correct):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35004522/216888612-02f51563-71cb-4b2a-8b04-86c5173e6a1b.png)

### Steps to reproduce the bug

[gt32_arm.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/10660065/gt32_arm.zip)

```
$ angr-management gt32_arm
```

### Environment

title: LoweredSwitchSimplifier: Fix a potential infinite loop.
DivSimplifier: Fix uses of DivMod.
Decompiler: Be more resilient against case nodes that are shared between switches.
Variable Recovery: Fixing stack offset calculation for complex stack operations
body:
Prior code would incorrectly calculate the stack offset from complex instructions.

One example of this (in x86_64) is: `mov rax, [rbp+rax*0x8-0x98]` which is translated into an AIL instruction like the following:

```
stack_base-8 + (Cons(32->64, *(stack_base-184)) * 0x8)) - 0x98
```

This results in a claripy AST addr of:

```
stack_base + 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF8 + top - 0x98
```

The old code would only extract the `0x98` as the offset, which conflicted with another variable on the stack (thus confusing those variables).

The fix that I have here is essentially to traverse the AST addr, and treat every symbolic value as 0.

Also, the old code was hard coded to only support adds of length 1 or 2, however in the example that I found the add had 3 elements. 

So the fix can now support an unlimited number of arguments to add.

I was not sure if this happened for sub as well, so I just left it hardcoded to support two arguments as before.

Another problem with the old code is that it used `BVV(0)` which could never work: it was not imported and it didn't specify the size.

Added a test case to check for this on the binary where I found this (babyheap_1.1):
https://github.com/angr/binaries/pull/103

title: Phoenix: Fix a leftover conditional jump after ITE structuring.
Variable Recovery: Make constant choice in the case of reading memory of overlapping variables
body:
This line in variable recovery causes non-deterministic results, because `all_vars` is a set:
https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/wip/constant-overlapping-vars/angr/analyses/variable_recovery/engine_base.py#L627

At least with this fix the choice will be deterministic. 

@ltfish reviewed and approved on slack

title: tests/README.md is out-of-date
body:
### Description

https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/master/tests/README.md describes how to use nose to run tests, but nose is no longer working out-of-box for Python 3.10+ (because of [collections.abc.Callable](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/69515086/error-attributeerror-collections-has-no-attribute-callable-using-beautifu/73353426#73353426)). We should update this page to reflect the latest suggestions on how to run angr tests locally.

Thanks @adamdoupe for reporting.

### Question

Hello. I am trying to display a graph of nodes. 

I can display 10 nodes with ease but after I encounter a certain indirect jump, the graph stops printing nodes and edges.  I've tried stepping over and seeing what the value of the RSI register was and it pointed to the correct path. If I run a simulation with proj.factory.simgr, it also continues on the same path without error.

I read the source code from cfg_emulated.py couldn't find anything related to a "max number of blocks to hold".

Any help would be appreciated,I've attached related pictures and code below.

```python
from bingraphvis import DotOutput
```

body:
### Description

Running `ruff` on `angr` master gives back multiple undefined name errors.

Some of these are likely due to typos, like `Pendingjob` should probably be `PendingJob`; some are likely due to python2, like `reduce` is no longer a python builtin but rather part of functools. Etc.

We could remove check on the autogenerated code (or maybe we want to fix the autogenerated code generators).

If all errors below are resolved by a given PR, it should also no longer disable this check in `pyproject.toml`.

IndexError on memory store with Concat operation
body:
### Description

Recently introduced code in angr >= v9.2.29 ([9995e2958bb248bbfd2e30ecde0c20acd0ab5853](https://github.com/angr/angr/commit/9995e2958bb248bbfd2e30ecde0c20acd0ab5853)) to split memory stores which use the Concat operation seems to result in the following error:

```
  ...
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/unwrapper_mixin.py", line 8, in store
    return super().store(_raw_ast(addr), _raw_ast(data),
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/name_resolution_mixin.py", line 54, in store
    return super().store(addr, data, size=size, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/bvv_conversion_mixin.py", line 25, in store
    super().store(addr, data_bv, size=size, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/simplification_mixin.py", line 11, in store
    super().store(addr, real_data, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/clouseau_mixin.py", line 41, in store
    super().store(addr, data,
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/actions_mixin.py", line 34, in store
    super().store(addr, data, size=size, action=action, condition=condition, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/underconstrained_mixin.py", line 27, in store
    super().store(addr, data, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/size_resolution_mixin.py", line 88, in store
    super().store(addr, data, size=size, condition=condition, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/size_resolution_mixin.py", line 47, in store
    super().store(addr, data, size=out_size, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/address_concretization_mixin.py", line 325, in store
    self._store_one_addr(addr, data, True, addr, condition, size, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/address_concretization_mixin.py", line 319, in _store_one_addr
    super().store(concrete_addr, data, size=size, condition=sub_condition, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/actions_mixin.py", line 74, in store
    return super().store(addr, data, action=action, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/conditional_store_mixin.py", line 17, in store
    super().store(addr, data, size=size, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/convenient_mappings_mixin.py", line 44, in store
    return super().store(addr, data, size=size, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/dirty_addrs_mixin.py", line 8, in store
    super().store(addr, data, size=size, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/paged_memory/paged_memory_mixin.py", line 186, in store
    sub_data, sub_data_base, sub_data_size = sub_gen.send(sub_size - written_size)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/angr/storage/memory_mixins/paged_memory/pages/cooperation.py", line 109, in _decompose_objects
    cur_data = data.args[start_offset].concat(*data.args[start_offset + 1:start_offset + size])
IndexError: tuple index out of range
```

`data.args[start_offset]` seems problematic, as args is a tuple of symbolic arguments, but it is being indexed by a memory offset.

### Steps to reproduce the bug

Perform a memory store on an AST which involves a Concat operation on a state which uses paged memory; I think the object size must also be larger than the page size. For instance, 
```st.memory.store(0xbe000000, claripy.Concat(claripy.BVS('foo', 3000 * 8), claripy.BVS('bar', 5000 * 8)))```
(where `st` is an `angr.SimState`) will reproduce the error if the page size is 4096 bytes.

### Environment

My environment is somewhat noncompliant with recommended defaults due to conflicts with other packages in use:

- Installed without a virtual environment (in a Docker container).
- Unicorn version 2.0.0 is installed, which is incompatible with angr, but I am not using Unicorn mode.

I don't think these impact this issue, but let me know if it is not reproducible.

Output of `python3 -m angr.misc.bug_report`:


title: Fix fp rounding not to cut off high values
body:
This PR tries to implement the following TODO:

```py
# engines/vex/claripy/irop.py:996
# _op_fgeneric_Round
        else:
            # note: this a bad solution because it will cut off high values
            # TODO: look into fixing this
```

The change exploits the observation that if the exponent of a floating point is high enough, the value is already an integer. Therefore, it is possible to return the value directly. As far as I know, this also works well with special values such as inf and NaN.

One downside of this method is that this adds one layer of If-Then-Else. Therefore, if you think the downside is not acceptable to your design, feel free to reject this.

Also, please confirm the values since I may have mistakes there.

title: Different disassembly results between block.pp() and arm-none-eabi-objdump
body:
### Description

In harness.py, I used angr to load an ARM elf (Drone.elf) and pretty-print the assembly of its entry block. It gave
```Reset_Handler:
8004f45 lsls r1, r4, #0xc
8004f47 lsrs r0, r4, #0xf
```

However, when I used "arm-none-eabi-objdump -D Drone.elf >Drone.objdump.disasm" to disassemble the elf file, the entry became

```08004f44 <Reset_Handler>:
8004f44: 2100 movs r1, #0
8004f46: e003 b.n 8004f50 <LoopCopyDataInit>
```

I tried to figure out the reason with the following capstone code:
```
from capstone import *
cs = Cs(CS_ARCH_ARM, CS_MODE_MCLASS | CS_MODE_THUMB)
with open('./Drone.bin', 'rb') as f: binCode = f.read()
for i in cs.disasm(binCode[ 0x4f44 : 0x4f48 ], 0x8004f44):
  print('0x%x:\t%s\t%s' % (i.address, i.mnemonic, i.op_str))
for i in cs.disasm(binCode[ 0x4f45 : 0x4f49 ], 0x8004f45):
  print('0x%x:\t%s\t%s' % (i.address, i.mnemonic, i.op_str))
```

The above prints out

```0x8004f44: movs r1, #0
0x8004f46: b #0x8004f50
0x8004f45: lsls r1, r4, #0xc
0x8004f47: lsrs r0, r4, #0xf
```

Therefore, I wonder if angr did not notice that the oddity of the entry address is to denote the THUMB mode, and if angr directly used 0x8004f45 as the literal entry address.

### Steps to reproduce the bug

The attached zip file contains the tested elf file (Drone.elf), its bin file (Drone.bin), the objdump results (Drone.objdump.disasm), and my angr Python script (harness.py).
[test_Drone_elf.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/10242321/test_Drone_elf.zip)

### Environment

Ubuntu 18.04.6 LTS
Python 3.8.0
angr 9.2.28
capstone 5.0.0
unicorn 2.0.1.post1

### Additional context

The angr slack channel (help) has some discussions about this issue. Although the elf file is for ARM Cortex-M, and this was not specified in the angr project constructor, project.arch still showed <Arch ARMCortexM (LE)>. Also, specifying arch='cortex-m' did not resolve the issue.

title: CFG generation is really slow sometimes on binaries with many indirect jumps
body:
### Description

Since commit 61090316d8a81751903cb8c2d7cb0456f9d1d99a (I've tested this commit and an early one), It seems the process cfg get generated is switched to a new one. And you can see many ERRORs in logs:
```
ERROR    | 2022-12-15 15:17:24,516 | angr.analyses.propagator.engine_vex.SimEnginePropagatorVEX | Unsupported Binop XXX
```

For certain binaries, it's getting really slow to generate CFG. In my case, a 1.5MB binary took 6 minute.
```
ERROR    | 2022-12-15 16:38:41,437 | angr.analyses.propagator.engine_vex.SimEnginePropagatorVEX | Unsupported Binop Iop_64HLtoV128.
# ... a lot of ERRORs
ERROR    | 2022-12-15 16:49:48,406 | angr.analyses.propagator.engine_vex.SimEnginePropagatorVEX | Unsupported Binop Iop_MullS32.
done after 369.8980860710144s
```

### Steps to reproduce the bug

```python
import angr
import logging
import time

logging.getLogger('pyvex.lifting.libvex').setLevel(logging.ERROR)

project = angr.Project(
    './lib.so',
    load_options={'auto_load_libs': False}
)

start_time = time.time()
print('generating cfg')
cfg = project.analyses.CFGFast(normalize=True, force_complete_scan=False)

print(f'done after {time.time() - start_time}s')
```

A sample arm64 binary:
[lib.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/10235256/lib.zip)



### Environment

No problem, within 1 minutes: before 72077cac9c9aff89e078b81d7b19c6bb8604f9d3
Logged errors, over 4 minutes: since 61090316d8a81751903cb8c2d7cb0456f9d1d99a

### Additional context

_No response_

- Fix an incorrect jump removal (leading to missing break statements inside loop bodies) in Dream.

- Fix a missing goto statement.

title: Phoenix: Fix a crash caused by empty nodes in MultiNode instances.
Phoenix: Ensure graph edges exist before removing in cyclic refinement.
Phoenix: Fix the overly strict condition for if-then matching.
ConditionProcessor: Fix conversion of single-bit boolean AIL consts.
Fix an infinite loop in CStructuredCodeGenerator._access.
Phoenix: Fix an infinite loop when structuring jump tables with cases going to the loop headers.
GotoSimplifier: Fix the missing successor when processing else nodes in CascadingConditionNodes.
Phoenix: Fix the duplication of default cases in switch-cases.
Phoenix: Add a while-true-cond-break graph schema.

title: Bug in SimEngineRDVEX: Some memory stores are ignored

labels.name: retest
labels.description: The test case in this issue is old and should be retested to see if the problem still exists

body:
### Description

The `if.. elif` construct for handling stores fails to consider addresses which are bitvectors. As a result such stores are ignored and this results in an incomplete dependency graph.

### Steps to reproduce the bug

This binary can be used to reproduce the issue (I compiled it without PIE):
```c
#include <stdio.h>

int global_int = 0;

void main(int argc, char** argv) {
	global_int++;
	return;
}
```

Here is the python script:
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import angr
import angr.analyses.reaching_definitions.dep_graph as dep_graph

path = "/home/schlaf/angr-dev/angr/bug/test_binary"
p = angr.Project(path, auto_load_libs=False)

cfg = p.analyses.CFGFast()

main_fun_addr = 0x00401106
main_fun = cfg.functions.get_by_addr(main_fun_addr)

d = dep_graph.DepGraph()

rd = p.analyses.ReachingDefinitions(subject=main_fun, dep_graph=d, track_calls=True)

graph = d.graph
for e in graph.edges:
    print(e)
```

You can see that an edge, which represents the store to `global_int` is missing.
If we fix this, then `(<Definition {Atom:<Reg 16<8>>, Codeloc:<0x401117 id=0x401106[38] contextless>}>, <Definition {Atom:<Mem 0x404014<4>>, Codeloc:<0x40111a id=0x401106[43] contextless>}>)` appears.

I will open a pull request soon.

### Environment

Your report script does not work for some reason. I confirmed this bug in an angr-dev environment. The last commit on angr is: 71987233ff3fdbb3fa404970a7a56057cbb9ec0d from Nov 7th.

### Additional context

_No response_

title: _handle_CmpLT in SimEngineLightVEXMixin did some <= comparision?
body:
### Question

As handler of `CmpLT` in class SimEngineLightVEXMixin (in `angr/engines/light/engine.py`), the code did some `expr_0 <= expr_1` operation. I didn't find any documentation about this. Is it correct?

```py
    def _handle_CmpLT(self, expr):
        args, r = self._binop_get_args(expr)
        if args is None: return r
        expr_0, expr_1 = args

        if self._is_top(expr_0) or self._is_top(expr_1):
            return self._top(1)

        return expr_0 <= expr_1
```

title: SimLinux: Fix uninitialized high 32 bits of the argc on stack.
body:
This issue is causing value loading from `envp` to contain an unconstrained symbolic variable, which leads to several test cases ending up in infinite loops. It is only exposed by https://github.com/angr/claripy/pull/310 since unconstrained symbolic variables were frequently evaluated as 0 in the past (due to empty cached models) when `ModelCacheMixin` is enabled.

This PR fixes the hanging angr CI.

title: Logging is impossible to read on a black terminal
body:
### Description

When using angr, logging messages will sometimes print bits in black, even on a black/dark terminal; this is hard / impossible to read.

That is because we sometimes color messages as black:
https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/c88d47e35a6f980528881d706f9a2cb2aaab6702/angr/misc/loggers.py#L72

Instead of black, we should use 'default'. (This is the reason we don't use white and do `%7` rather than `%8` on that line)

### Steps to reproduce the bug

Cause some log messages in a dark terminal

### Environment

Master: https://github.com/angr/angr/commit/c88d47e35a6f980528881d706f9a2cb2aaab6702

### Additional context

_No response_

title: angr log formatter length not respected
body:
### Description

The log format isn't respected in angr, specifically length fields. I.e. given the format `'%(levelname)-7s | %(asctime)-23s | %(name)-8s | %(message)s'`:
If the name is `abc`, we will still end up with `| abc |`.

This is almost certainly because of the 0-width coloring characters; that is, `| abc |` is indeed more than 8 bytes long as it contains 2 ascii escape sequences.

To fix this we'd need a custom formatter

### Steps to reproduce the bug

Trigger any log message with a log name of less than 8 bytes

### Environment

angr master

### Additional context

_No response_

title: `angr` corrupts log records
body:
### Description

`angr` corrupts log records so subsequent log handlers cannot use them cleanly (for example, it injects ascii escape codes to color log output into the log record). It does so here: 
https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/bd89ce4fcf76619c8aeb06d1746ae5939ea5d800/angr/misc/loggers.py#L74 and https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/bd89ce4fcf76619c8aeb06d1746ae5939ea5d800/angr/misc/loggers.py#L79

There are 3 obvious fixes to this:
1. Copy the log record before editing it- the downside is the overhead of a log record copy on each log
2. Convert our custom handler to a custom formatter, do _not_ call `super().format(record)` in it; this removes the ability for users to set custom format strings for the angr logger, unless we roll that ourself.
3. Convert our custom handler to a custom formatter, parse the output of `super().format(record)` and adapt it- this is the wrong option.

I think 2 is ok if the overhead of 1 is worry-some. We already define our own format (which itself does not work). Additionally, if 2 is implemented, `angr` will no longer corrupt records so users can add their own log handlers easily if they desire something special.

### Steps to reproduce the bug

```python
import angr
import logging
logging.getLogger().addHandler(logging.StreamHandler())
logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
logging.info("abc")
```

The final line outputs:
```
>>> logging.info("abc")
INFO    | 2022-10-28 17:22:06,680 | root | abc
abc
```

Note that both `abc` strings are colored; which means angr corrupts the log record the stream handler uses.

### Environment

Master: https://github.com/angr/angr/commit/691ec5ec220301be7aabf8650adaeb6cf1006421

### Additional context

_No response_

some default types alignment raise exceptions
body:
when accessing `alignment` of some types definied in `ALL_TYPES`, it raises `TypeError` or `ValueError`.
you can trigger it with
```python
[v.alignment for v in angr.types.ALL_TYPES.values()]
```

the list of currently failings types are:
* `TypeError: '>' not supported between instances of 'NotImplementedType' and 'NotImplementedType'`
  * `$_IO_wide_data`, `__mbstate_t`, `aiocb`, `aiocb64`, `obstack`, `sigevent`, `sigval`
* `ValueError: max() arg is an empty sequence`
  * `$_IO_codecvt`, `_IO_iconv_t`, `_IO_lock_t`, `argp_child`, `argp_state`, `drand48_data`, `random_data`

the `ValueError` is triggered by zero field struct, used when forward declaring some self-referencing types.

title: IFuncResolver breaks functionality of Project.hook_symbol
body:
<!--
*Disclaimer:
The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers.
While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best.
For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](https://angr.io/invite/)*
-->
---

**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->

angr currently inserts `IFuncResolver`s by directly writing to the GOT: https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/3090a97c73a74187f3bfdb85aa61856d064569f5/angr/simos/linux.py#L121-L124

As a result, if someone tries to hook the corresponding symbol (e.g., `strrchr`) with their own simproc, the new simproc will not be invoked.

**To Reproduce.**
<!--
Please include *both a script to reproduce the crash, and attach the binary used, if possible*
-->

1. Load an ELF program that imports `strrchr`.
2. Use `Project.hook_symbol` to hook `strrchr` with an arbitrary simproc.
3. Step into `strrchr`'s PLT and observe that the new simproc is not invoked.

Include ins_addr in CodeLocation
body:
- Not having `ins_addr` in code location results in the same hash value for two code locations with the same `stmt_idx` but different `ins_addr`.
- This situation arises when you are performing simplifications on a block that results in certain statements being removed, so the statement id now points to a different instruction.
- The reason this is a problem is that when a new AST is created, `claripy `has a cache, where it checks to see if the AST has already been created. But since `ins_addr `is not included in the hash of the annotation, there is a possibility that a new AST annotation with a different `ins_addr `but same `stmt_idx `already exists in the cache. So it returns this AST with the annotation that has the incorrect `ins_addr`

**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
When trying to load a binary using blob backend (for an android firmware) the binary file is divided in segments but 2 of those segments are empty, as soon as the program gets an empty segment it will throw an error (Backer Empty) and stop. The issue was solved for elf files on a 2021 commit by making the if not data: statement return instead of rise ErrorValue() and then in elf.py marked those empty segments to avoid using them. I'm facing the issue in a blob (as previously stated).

title: AIL optimization may incorrectly collapse `Convert`s
body:
I've found at least three spots in Clinic optimization path where necessary expression narrowing is mistakenly discarded, i.e `Conv(32->64, Conv(64->32, X))` may become `Conv(64->64, X)` or `X`, leaving the top 32b uncleared:
* AIL Propagator
* RemoveCascadingConversions
* DivSimplifier, MultiSimplifier, and ModSimplifier

Minimal:

```python
p = angr.load_shellcode('''
    mov eax, edi
    ret
    ''', arch='AMD64')
cfg = p.analyses.CFG(normalize=True)

f = p.kb.functions['_start']
f.pp()
print()

p.factory.block(0).vex.pp()
print()

c = p.analyses.Clinic(f, cfg=cfg)
for n in c.graph.nodes:
    print(n)
    print()
```

```
   _start:
0  mov     eax, edi
2  ret     

IRSB {
   t0:Ity_I64 t1:Ity_I64 t2:Ity_I64 t3:Ity_I64 t4:Ity_I32 t5:Ity_I64 t6:Ity_I64 t7:Ity_I64

   00 | ------ IMark(0x0, 2, 0) ------
   01 | t5 = GET:I64(rdi)
   02 | t4 = 64to32(t5)
   03 | t3 = 32Uto64(t4)
   04 | PUT(rax) = t3
   05 | PUT(rip) = 0x0000000000000002
   06 | ------ IMark(0x2, 1, 0) ------
   07 | t0 = GET:I64(rsp)
   08 | t1 = LDle:I64(t0)
   09 | t2 = Add64(t0,0x0000000000000008)
   10 | PUT(rsp) = t2
   11 | t6 = Sub64(t2,0x0000000000000080)
   12 | ====== AbiHint(0xt6, 128, t1) ======
   NEXT: PUT(rip) = t1; Ijk_Ret
}

## Block 0
00 | 0x2 | return rdi<8>;
```

With some patches, this becomes:
```
## Block 0
00 | 0x2 | return Conv(32->64, Conv(64->32, rdi<8>));
```

Probably some issues with sign extension too. Definitely needs some test cases.

title: VFG raises an error when handling multiple successor states
body:
**Describe the bug.**
Angr's VFG recovery assumes every state has only a single successor state, which is not always the case.

**Environment Information.**
```

```

**To Reproduce.**
Run the following script. The binary that was used is the same binary that is used in the `test_vfg_resolving_indirect_calls` test in `test_vfg.py`.
```python
import os

import angr
from angr.analyses.cfg.indirect_jump_resolvers.resolver import IndirectJumpResolver

class FuncChainResolver(IndirectJumpResolver):
    def __init__(self, project):
        super().__init__(project, timeless=True)

    def filter(self, cfg, addr, func_addr, block, jumpkind):
        return jumpkind == "Ijk_Call"

    def resolve(self, cfg, addr, func_addr, block, jumpkind):
        vfg = self.project.analyses.VFG(
            cfg,
            start=addr,
            context_sensitivity_level=1,
            interfunction_level=1,
            record_function_final_states=True,
        )

        indirect_call_targets = []
        for vfg_node in vfg.get_all_nodes(addr):
            for successor_state in vfg_node.final_states:
                if successor_state.history.jumpkind == "Ijk_Call":
                    indirect_call_targets.append(successor_state.addr)

        print(indirect_call_targets)

        return (True, indirect_call_targets)

def main():
    p = angr.Project(
        os.path.join("aarch64", "func-chain-aarch64"),
        auto_load_libs=False,
    )

    p.analyses.CFGEmulated(
        indirect_jump_resolvers = [r(p) for r in [
            angr.analyses.cfg.indirect_jump_resolvers.ConstantResolver,
            FuncChainResolver,
        ]],
    )

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

```
  File "~/code.py", line 33, in resolve
    vfg = self.project.analyses.VFG(

  File "~/angr-dev/angr/angr/analyses/analysis.py", line 122, in wrapper

  File "~/angr-dev/angr/angr/analyses/vfg.py", line 721, in <listcomp>

  File "~/angr-dev/angr/angr/state_plugins/solver.py", line 776, in eval_one
```

title: Why solutions generated by angr can not be reproduced?
body:
<!--
*Disclaimer:
The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers.
While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best.
For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](https://angr.io/invite/)*
-->

<!--

**Tips:**

Before submitting, make sure that you:

* Search the Issues page for a similar question.
* Search the [Documentation](https://docs.angr.io/) for an answer, as well as our library of [examples](https://github.com/angr/angr-doc/tree/master/examples)
* Are running the latest versions of angr and its components.  angr is rapidly-evolving!
* Ask your question on [Slack](https://angr.io/invite/) instead, if it is brief.

-->

---

<!--
Ask your question here.
-->
Dear developers,

May I ask a question here, which I was issued in [Slack](https://app.slack.com/docs/T03LGALRN/F036S91FJAW) but it seems no responses yet? Here, I just copy most of the content and look forward to your suggestions or ideas. Thank you so much in advance!

The question is about why the solutions generated by `angr` can not be reproduced? Please check the following example for more details. The unreproduced binary `b-gcc-O1` is compiled under `gcc-11` with `-O1` optimization option, which takes a string as input. (I used `argv[1]` to pass the argument in the source code program).

My goal here is to use `angr` is to feed a symbolic input to the target binary (e.g., `b-gcc-O1`) and then let it automatically find all possible execution paths in that binary. I expect the generated solutions by `angr` could help exactly reproduce the execution paths which are explored before. (I think reproducibility could be the most powerful weapon in symbolic execution, right?). However, it seems not so true exactly.

Here is the script (`angr-test.py`) I used:
```
import angr
import claripy
import sys

target_binary = sys.argv[1]

sym_input = claripy.BVS("sym_input", 8*2)
p = angr.Project(target_binary, load_options={'auto_load_libs': False})
state = p.factory.entry_state(args=[target_binary, sym_input], add_options={angr.options.ZERO_FILL_UNCONSTRAINED_MEMORY, angr.options.ZERO_FILL_UNCONSTRAINED_REGISTERS})
sm = p.factory.simulation_manager(state)
sm.run()
print(sm)

# constrain the symbolic input to fall within printable range
for byte in sym_input.chop(bits=8):
    state.add_constraints(byte >= 'A'.encode(), byte <= 'Z'.encode())

for i in range(len(sm.deadended)):
    print("No.", i, " solution:")
    print("output: ", sm.deadended[i].posix.dumps(1).decode('utf-8'))
    print("input: ", sm.deadended[i].posix.dumps(sys.stdin.fileno()))
    b = sm.deadended[i].solver.eval(sym_input, cast_to=bytes).rstrip(b'\x00')
    print("org b: ", b)
    print("hex b: ", b.decode("utf-8", "ignore"))
```
Then I run `python3 angr-test.py b-gcc-O1` and got the following outputs:
```
$ python3 angr-test.py b-gcc-O1
<SimulationManager with 4 deadended>
No. 0  solution:
output:  0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 
input:  b''
org b:  b'+3'
hex b:  +3
No. 1  solution:
output:  0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 
input:  b''
org b:  b'7g'
hex b:  7g
No. 2  solution:
output:  0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 
input:  b''
org b:  b'c1'
hex b:  c1
No. 3  solution:
output:  0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 
input:  b''
org b:  b'\x0ff'
hex b:  f
```
The numbers in the output indicate a set of block `id`s (`c` = continue; `b` = break ) which are executed by each state (by calling `printf("id");` in source code of `b-gcc-O1`).
Then, when I try to reproduce the explored paths (sequence of numbers) using the resolved solution given by `angr`, I can not make it. Here are the reproducing results:
```
$ ./b-gcc-O1 "+3"
0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b
$ ./b-gcc-O1 "7g"
0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b
$ ./b-gcc-O1 "c1"
0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 
$ ./b-gcc-O1 "\x0ff"
0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 
```
It seems only one (No.0 with input `+3`) of the solutions can be reproduced with the corresponding paths reported by `angr`'s execution (by `python3 angr-test.py b-gcc-O1`). I guess `angr` should not behave like that, right? Did I mistakenly use `angr` or anything I missed here? 

A possible reason behind this may be that does`angr` have some trouble dealing with a binary compiled with higher compiler optimizations? To say why I re-compiled the source code with `gcc-11 -O0` to generate a new binary `b-gcc-O0` and use `angr` again. Here are the new outputs:
```

59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 
input:  b''
org b:  b'Cf'
hex b:  Cf
No. 2  solution:
output:  0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 84 145 b 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 
63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63
 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 
input:  b''
org b:  b'1\xb5'
hex b:  1
No. 3  solution:
output:  0 3 6 c 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 
59 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59
 63 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 3 6 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 63 63 63 63 12 16 16 16 16 22 54 59 6
3 63 63 63 6 c 6 c 6 c 87 92 92 92 92 145 b 
input:  b''
org b:  b'D0'
hex b:  D0
```
This time I can reproduce the solution as the anger reported before.

So, could you please help check what could be the problems here? Is the wrong usage of mine or a possible issue in `angr`? If it's the latter case, in what situations that solutions given by `angr` can not be reproduced (except environment modeling barriers in symbolic execution, e.g., usage of syscalls)? The tested binary does not involve many environmental issues here.

I tested the binaries in a ubuntu 18.04 system using `angr-dev` version and here are the used binaries:
[b-gcc-O1 and b-gcc-O0.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/8239805/b-gcc-O1.and.b-gcc-O0.zip)

Thank you so much for your help and look forward to your insightful reply!

Best regards,
Haoxin

title: CC: Resilience: Treat the bottom type as an int type.

Errored state getting pruned
body:
Hi,
I went through something a bit tricky, so I wanted to check if this is a mistake or the intended behaviour.
I had a program running in a simulation manager, and a breakpoint was fired. Inside the breakpoint function, I was using the `solver.eval()` method without checking the expression's satisfiability (shame on me), so an unsat error was raised. The error got silently caught inside `SimulationManager.step_state()` which pruned the state.
Shouldn't this state go to the "errored" stash instead?

title: Correctly handle partial pending memory reads
body: Previously, we were handling partial pending reads not yet associated with a memory read instruction too late. This resulted in #3092 when checking if all reads at the last processed memory read instruction are done. This PR fixes #3092 by processing partial reads earlier.

title: Structurer: Fix a crash when creating loop break nodes.
return default if block addr not found in recognized blocks
skip slice nodes if block_stmt_idx is invalid
added check that node is in list before calling remove
Multiple fixes in CCA, RDA, and other places.
VariableManager: Only reuse phi vars for variables created in the same block.
body:
This commit solves the issue that unrelated and unaccessed variables may
be added to an existing cluster of variables (governed by the same phi
variable). By limiting the reuse of phi variables, when an unrelated
variable U is added to an existing cluster of variables that already
have a phi variable A, we will create a new phi node B that governs
both A and U. This way it allows us to track if B is accessed or not
(instead of only tracking if A is accessed).

title: CFGFast: Fix several corner cases in function returning detection.
Fix the timeout issue in test_floating_point_memory_reads.
body:
This test case may require hundreds of _max() calls to determine a
maximum read/write address during address concretization in some cases
(there is a non-determinism based on which memory bytes are
overwritten). Forcing it to use any-strategy solves the problem.

Fix the missing arch argument when calling refine_locs_with_struct_type().

tracer exploration: Fix qemu block contained in unicorn block check
body:
This PR implements the following fixes to the qemu block contained in unicorn block check(introduced in #2588):

1. We do not need to compare the block at `last_match_index` in trace and `big_block_start` since they are the same.
2. All checks should check for strict containment: the block in qemu trace should not overlap with `big_block_start`(since the block at `last_match_index` already does). This prevents some trace desyncs being incorrectly deemed as not a desync.

I am not sure why worker 2 timed out in CI run for the branch: AFAIK there is no test case that exercises this code(the only CGC binary where I know this happens is KPRCA_00046, which angr takes a long time to trace).

body:
<!--
*Disclaimer:

---

**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
The calling convention result for some of the functions in the challenge_5 binary is incorrect. E.g. expecting 5 arguments, but angr says 0.
```
Func 1: Expecting 0 arguments
[]

Func 2: Expecting 5 arguments
[]

Func 3: Expecting 5 arguments
[]

Func 4:Expecting 3 arguments
[<r0>, <r1>, <r2>]
```

**Environment Information.**
<!--
Many common issues are caused by problems with the local Python environment.
Before submitting, double-check that your versions of all modules in the angr suite (angr, cle, pyvex, ...) are up to date.
Please include the output of `python -m angr.misc.bug_report` here.
-->
angr version: angr-9.0.gitrolling

**To Reproduce.**
<!--
Please include *both a script to reproduce the crash, and attach the binary used, if possible*
-->
```
import angr

def get_func_by_addr(p, addr):
    func = p.kb.functions.get_by_addr(addr)
    func.normalize()
    return func

path = '../challenge_05/program_c.gcc.vuln'
p = angr.Project(path, load_options={'auto_load_libs': False})
cfg = p.analyses.CFGFast(normalize=True, show_progressbar=True, data_references=True, force_complete_scan=False, function_starts={0x11169, })
p.analyses.CompleteCallingConventions(recover_variables=True)

func_1 = get_func_by_addr(p, 0x16621)
print("\nFunc 1: Expecting 0 arguments")
print(func_1.calling_convention.args)

func_2 = get_func_by_addr(p, 0x16fe1)
print("\nFunc 2: Expecting 5 arguments")
print(func_2.calling_convention.args)

func_3 = get_func_by_addr(p, 0x16819)
print("\nFunc 3: Expecting 5 arguments")
print(func_3.calling_convention.args)

func_4 = get_func_by_addr(p, 0x16849)
print("\nFunc 4:Expecting 3 arguments")
print(func_4.calling_convention.args)

```

**Additional context.**

Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

title: Fix bug in decompilation when a string contains a single quote, the g…

title: Decompilation is not valid when there is double quote in string
CStructuredCodeGen: Do not unify types for variables around a binary operator.
Propagator: Fix a None accessing issue in the AIL engine.
CCA: Fix register argument detection in callsite analysis.
LoopSimplifier: for loop iterators cannot be control-transferring statements.
Propagator: Tighten the call expression replacement check.
Structurer: Addresses multiple causes for non-determinism.
body:
- SequenceNodes should keep their addresses unchanged during
simplification.

- Structurer only removes conditional jumps after the entire region has
finished being structured.

- Sub nodes in each switch case should keep their order unchanged (stay
in topological order).

- If-then-else branches are always ordered by node addresses.

This PR requires https://github.com/angr/angr/pull/2891.

title: Clinic: Assign an idx to Call.ret_expr expressions.
body:
This fix addresses the issue where AIL simplifiers may replace more
expressions (in this case, replacing the return expression of a call
statement if one of its arguments is the same as, i.e., likes, its
return expression) than necessary.

title: fix over-filtering in arm_thumb_filter_jump_successors

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body:
Constant can be directly loaded in ```itstate``` register, but ```_arm_thumb_filter_jump_successors``` does not handle with this case (it only considers constant in tmp) and overly filter some successors. Therefore, angr fails to recover some blocks and edges for Arm thumb binary. 

I attach the pyvex IR and assembly/disassembly code (where constant is directly loaded) below:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12579777/132016371-f1508845-bcf5-4d64-afcb-3619c57c01ff.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12579777/132016563-401654b5-2996-4606-8b16-f5021ec3f636.png)

title: indirect call resolution correctly propagates gp value from stack
body:
previously were only doing gp_value resolution for first block then breaking out of loop
now does for all blocks in slice. also added wrapper code so if resolution is possible on
smaller max_level in Blade() then it will return that instead (slight efficiency improvement)

**To Reproduce.**
<!--

```
import angr, monkeyhex
from claripy import Annotation

class TestingAnnotation(Annotation):
    def __init__(self, random):
        super(TestingAnnotation, self).__init__()

        self.random = random

    @property
    def eliminatable(self):
        return False

    @property
    def relocatable(self):
        return False

    def __hash__(self):
        return hash(('stack_location', self.random))

    def __eq__(self, other):
        if not isinstance(other, TestingAnnotation):
            return False

        return self.random == other.random

proj = angr.Project('/bin/true')
state = proj.factory.entry_state()
print(hex(id(state.regs.rdx)))
anno = state.regs.rdx.annotate(TestingAnnotation(1))
print(hex(id(anno)))
state.regs.rdx = anno
print(hex(id(state.regs.rdx)))
print(state.regs.rdx.annotations)
```

The output is following: 
```
0x7ff032a5b450
0x7ff03057be10
0x7ff032a5b450
()
```

As you can see, after assigning annotated value to ```state.regs.rdx```,  its content does not change. I do not know it is a feature or a bug. If it is a feature, could you give some hints on how to annotate register value? Thanks in advance!

```python
import angr
import claripy
from angr_targets import AvatarGDBConcreteTarget


GDB_SERVER_IP = '127.0.0.1'
GDB_SERVER_PORT = 9876

# First set everything up
binary_x64 = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)),
                                          os.path.join('..', 'binaries',
                                          'tests','x86_64',
                                          'packed_elf64'))

# Spawning of the gdbserver analysis environment
print("gdbserver %s:%s %s" % (GDB_SERVER_IP,GDB_SERVER_PORT,binary_x64))
subprocess.Popen("gdbserver %s:%s %s" % (GDB_SERVER_IP,GDB_SERVER_PORT,binary_x64),
                  stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
                  stderr=subprocess.PIPE,
                  shell=True)

# Instantiation of the AvatarGDBConcreteTarget
avatar_gdb = AvatarGDBConcreteTarget(avatar2.archs.x86.X86_64,
                                     GDB_SERVER_IP, GDB_SERVER_PORT)                                                                        

# Creation of the project with the new attributes 'concrete_target'
p = angr.Project(binary_x64, concrete_target=avatar_gdb,
                             use_sim_procedures=True)

entry_state = p.factory.entry_state()
entry_state.options.add(angr.options.SYMBION_SYNC_CLE)
entry_state.options.add(angr.options.SYMBION_KEEP_STUBS_ON_SYNC)

simgr = p.factory.simgr(entry_state)

## Now, let's the binary unpack itself
simgr.use_technique(angr.exploration_techniques.Symbion(find=[0x85b853]))
exploration = simgr.run()
new_concrete_state = exploration.stashes['found'][0]

# Hit the new stub 4 times before having our unpacked code at 0x400cd6
for i in range(0,4):
    simgr = p.factory.simgr(new_concrete_state)
    simgr.use_technique(angr.exploration_techniques.Symbion(find=[0x85b853]))
    exploration = simgr.run()
    new_concrete_state = exploration.stashes['found'][0]

## Reaching the first decision point
simgr = p.factory.simgr(new_concrete_state)
simgr.use_technique(angr.exploration_techniques.Symbion(find=[0x400cd6]))
exploration = simgr.run()
new_concrete_state = exploration.stashes['found'][0]
print("[1]exploration: " + str(exploration))

# Declaring a symbolic buffer
arg0 = claripy.BVS('arg0', 8*32)

# The address of the symbolic buffer would be the one of the
# hardcoded malware configuration
symbolic_buffer_address = new_concrete_state.regs.rbp-0xc0

# Setting the symbolic buffer in memory!
new_concrete_state.memory.store(symbolic_buffer_address, arg0)

simgr = p.factory.simgr(new_concrete_state)

DROP_STAGE2_V2 = 0x400d99
DROP_STAGE2_V1 = 0x400d6a
VENV_DETECTED = 0x400da5
FAKE_CC = 0x400db9

print("[2]Symbolically executing binary to find dropping of second stage" +
       "[ address:  " + hex(DROP_STAGE2_V2) + " ]")

# Symbolically explore the malware to find a specific behavior by avoiding
# evasive behaviors
exploration = simgr.explore(find=DROP_STAGE2_V2, avoid=[DROP_STAGE2_V1,
                                                       VENV_DETECTED, FAKE_CC ])
print("[2]exploration: " + str(exploration))

# Get our synchronized state back!
new_symbolic_state = exploration.stashes['found'][0]


print("[3]Executing binary concretely with solution found until the end " +
hex(BINARY_EXECUTION_END))

simgr = p.factory.simgr(new_symbolic_state)

# Concretizing the solution to reach the interesting behavior in the memory
# of the concrete process and resume until the end of the execution.
simgr.use_technique(angr.exploration_techniques.Symbion(find=[BINARY_EXECUTION_END],
                              memory_concretize = [(symbolic_buffer_address,arg0)],
                              register_concretize=[]))
                              
exploration = simgr.run()
new_concrete_state = exploration.stashes['found'][0]
```

title: Fix merged_to calculation in ultra_page.
body:
I noticed some bad merged happening where only part of the bytes were merging, splicing them.

In the concrete case, merged_to is incorrectly calculated as an absolute address instead of a page offset. This fixes it and prevents erroneous merging.

title: Fix: deduplicate Multivalues with same Definition when doing RDA
body: specify __hash__ and __eq__ for DefintionAnnotation, otherwise deduplication through set() does not work.

title: VRA: Fix two cases where operands are incorrectly sized.
ConstantDereferenceSimplifier: Segment.is_writable is a property.
Rebuild callgraph after loading angr DB.
MemoryObjectSetMixin: Properly handle cross-page writes.
RDA: Multiple robustness improvements.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

title: Use blocks obtained from self.blocks directly in instruction_size
body:
The [self.blocks](https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/c93d36514b572f5df841304befa7c6804044d81d/angr/knowledge_plugins/functions/function.py#L1186) used in `instruction_size` yields blocks created by [self.get_block(...)](https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/c93d36514b572f5df841304befa7c6804044d81d/angr/knowledge_plugins/functions/function.py#L239).
Therefore, it should not be necessary to use [self.get_block](https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/c93d36514b572f5df841304befa7c6804044d81d/angr/knowledge_plugins/functions/function.py#L1187) again in `instruction_size`.

This is a possible fix to Issue #2827, since this removes the reference to the invalid attribute `b.bytestr` for `Block` `b`.

title: CStructuredCodeGen: Fix two missing yielded items.
VRA: Fix the wrong temp variable in VEXEngine._handle_LLSC.
RegionIdentifier: Do not crash if the beginning node has a self loop.
CFGBase: Fix a crash in _process_irrational_function_starts() when blocks are empty.
CFGBase: Fix: Self-loops on the first node are incorrected marked as outside jumps.
CFGBase: Recognize single-node-with-self-loop alignment chunks.
fix pretty print to avoid priting something like char *a[3]
ListPage: Fix an issue of over-storing.
CFGBase: Do not crash if a return target does not exist in the binary.
VRA: Fix an uncaught SimMemoryMissingError.
LightEngine: Catch SimOperationError in Unop handler.
Decompiler: Fix duplication of arguments in variable lists.
body: This PR fixes https://github.com/angr/angr-management/issues/346.

title: MSVS does not support strcasestr
body:
<!--
*Disclaimer:
The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers.
While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best.
For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*
-->

**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->

MSVC does not support `strcasestr`, which is used [here](https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/cf54b8df34ce2da822e50e6347b892eff1f4b712/native/sim_unicorn.cpp#L993). We should replace it with `strstr` (with the correct case of `"cpuid"`, of course).

**Environment Information.**
<!--
Many common issues are caused by problems with the local Python environment.
Before submitting, double-check that your versions of all modules in the angr suite (angr, cle, pyvex, ...) are up to date.
Please include the output of `python -m angr.misc.bug_report` here.
-->

Windows 10 + VS 2019.

**To Reproduce.**
<!--
Please include *both a script to reproduce the crash, and attach the binary used, if possible*
-->

Build angr_native under VS 2019.

**Additional context.**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

title: Store addr for each CFunction.
ImportSourceCode: Fix a crash when the line number is incorrect.
CFGFast: Fix a crash in ARM binaries when accessing unmapped memory regions.
VRA: Fix a bug in finding existing stack variables.
CCodeGen: Fix the bug that arguments may appear in variable list.
AILSimplifier: Allow removing call expressions that are assigned to Stores.
BlockSimplifier: Eliminate dead assignments even when nothing is replaced.
DepGraph: Ignore dummy nodes.
Fix exits discovery in libc_start_main for certain ARMHF binaries.
body: When passed as a positional argument, `b` is ignored, which leads to re-lifting of each block. Re-lifted blocks in certain ARMHF binaries may disable `arm_allow_optimizing_lookback` , and then lead to incorrect execution result. Passing in `b` as a keyword argument can prevent angr from re-lifting the block.

title: RDA: Fix handling of DirtyStatements in AIL engine.
body: Note that this is not a complete fix. I still need to implement support for `CAS` in AIL (which is triggering tons of errors in the megatest).

title: CallSiteMaker: Fix the broken ret-addr removal.
Fix support of Mull in Propagator and AIL.
body: Sync: https://github.com/angr/ailment/pull/64

title: Constrain the now limited size of the write
body: Without this patch, the symbolic size passed to write is allowed to be enormous (0x100000000) because it's not actually constrained to match the behavior of the write.

title: Decompiler freezes trying to process MD5 core function
body:
Try decompiling the MD5Transform function in [md5c.o](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/6634225/md5c.o.gz). It takes longer than I care to wait.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2498805/121592731-eae25400-c9ef-11eb-858d-3af72a1905ee.png)

Seemingly, the culprit is `ailment.Expression.__eq__`, which makes sense since this will obviously create extremely deep ASTs. Do we want to add hash-consing to ailment?

title: SimOS: Assign SP after default symbolic registers
body:
The sp register may be present in default_symbolic_registers. If both
initial_prefix and stack_end are specified in a call to blank_state, the
calculated sp value may be clobbered.

This change initializes the default symbolic registers before setting
the sp value to prevent that case.

[Here](https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/9f3bbe6b085537e1d300774366f65381ca5f725e/angr/analyses/decompiler/structured_codegen.py#L306) accesses the `_arch` property of function prototype. However, the `_arch` of function prototypes may not be set. This PR fixes this issue.

<!--
Ask your question here.
-->
Getting an error when I run ReachingDefinitionsAnalysis on some binaries pointing to this line: https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/master/angr/analyses/reaching_definitions/engine_vex.py#L183 

Couple of questions related to this:
- CFGFast MUST be generated before doing a ReachingDefinitionsAnalysis. Should it be this way? This is probably a good assumption but I was using a CFGEmulated. Wondering if this can be changed to just use any CFG that's available?
- this get_all_nodes() function is returning an empty list in my situation and I'm getting a ListIndexError. Could this be because of a decoding/lifting error in my binary - a bunch of these errors print when I load the binary.

For now, I have made the following change in my local version of angr:

```python

function_address = (
self.project.kb
    .cfgs['CFGFast']
    .get_all_nodes(self._codeloc().ins_addr, anyaddr=True)[0]
    .function_address if len(self.project.kb
                             .cfgs['CFGFast']
                             .get_all_nodes(self._codeloc().ins_addr, anyaddr=True)) > 0 else 0
)
```

title: CFGFast: Make sure project.entry is always the first in the list.
body:
This commit solves the problem of missing edges between _start and
libc_start_main if libc_start_main is scanned before _start (and thus, a
CFGJob with src_node being None is used, which causes edges between
project.entry and libc_start_main not getting created).

title: Fix an issue related to CFGEmulated generated using base graph, and add a test case.
body:
### Problem
In one of my previous PR(#2469), I reused the ```should_skip``` flag to avoid processing duplicate CFG nodes. In that PR, I intended to **process the last block but skip those duplicate blocks before the last one**.
```
...
elif self._base_graph is not None and next((en for en in self._job_info_queue[1:] if en.job.block_id == block_id), None):
            should_skip = True
```
However, I didn't realize that the task of avoiding duplication has already been handled by another part of the code within ```_pre_job_handling()```, which **skips all the blocks that are traced more than ```_max_iterations_```(which is set to 1 initially)**:
``` 
if self._traced_addrs[job.call_stack_suffix][addr] >= self._max_iterations:
            should_skip = True
...
# Increment tracing count for this block
        self._traced_addrs[job.call_stack_suffix][addr] += 1
```
Therefore, if these two strategies are applied at the same time, **all the duplicate blocks will be skipped, without processing even once.**

### Solution
Since the task of avoiding processing duplicate CFG nodes has already been handled by the tracing count strategy, I can simply delete my added codes.
A test is also added for this issue.

title: Fix a bug in readv(). Close #2447.
Disable cross-insn-opt in IRSBs for indirect jump resolving. Close #2448.
IndexError when creating CFGEmulated on ARM thumb binary
body:
**Describe the bug.**
When running the CFGEmulated analysis on the attached ARM thumb binary, angr crashes with the following backtrace:

```
>>> import angr
>>> p = angr.Project("get")
>>> cfg = p.analyses.CFGEmulated()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/analysis.py", line 115, in __call__
    oself.__init__(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/cfg/cfg_emulated.py", line 306, in __init__
    self._analyze()
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/forward_analysis/forward_analysis.py", line 216, in _analyze
    self._analysis_core_baremetal()
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/forward_analysis/forward_analysis.py", line 368, in _analysis_core_baremetal
    self._process_job_and_get_successors(job_info)
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/forward_analysis/forward_analysis.py", line 386, in _process_job_and_get_successors
    successors = self._get_successors(job)
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/cfg/cfg_emulated.py", line 1295, in _get_successors
    resolved, resolved_targets, ij = self._indirect_jump_encountered(addr, cfg_node, irsb, func_addr,
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/cfg/cfg_base.py", line 2331, in _indirect_jump_encountered
    resolved, resolved_targets = self._resolve_indirect_jump_timelessly(addr, irsb, func_addr, jumpkind)
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/cfg/cfg_base.py", line 2274, in _resolve_indirect_jump_timelessly
    r, resolved_targets = res.resolve(self, addr, func_addr, block, jumpkind)
  File "/home/manuel/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/angr/analyses/cfg/indirect_jump_resolvers/arm_elf_fast.py", line 60, in resolve
    stmt = block.statements[stmt_idx]
IndexError: list index out of range
```


**Environment Information.**
```% pip show angr
Name: angr
Version: 9.0.5171
% python --version
Python 3.8.5
```


**To Reproduce.**
```
p = angr.Project("get")
cfg = p.analyses.CFGEmulated()
```

[get.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/5754289/get.zip)

Binary is from this reduced test case:
```c
__attribute__((noinline)) int get(void)
{
    volatile int stuff[100] = { 0x1000 };
    return stuff[0];
}

int main(int argc, char **argv)
{
        get();
}
```

compiled with `arm-none-eabi-gcc -mthumb -g -O2 get.c --specs=nosys.specs -o get`.

**Additional context.**
Only breaks with `-mthumb`.  Works with `-marm`.

title: Decompiler fails when handling return statements possibly due to issues identifying calling convention
body:
**Describe the bug.**

The decompiler fails to decompile a function when trying to handle return statements. Based on the traceback, it seems to be because the calling convention is somehow not determined/known when handling return statements. Looking at the blame history, it seems to be related to the latest commits implementing support for return statements in decompiler.

Unfortunately, I do not have a script: I was decompiling using angr-management. I am not 100% sure since I didn't reverse the function but did some context matching with source code and CFG.

Refactor CodeLocation and type its properties.
Fix  `accept` finds ident in a wrong way.
body:
`state.posix.fd` is a `SimFileDescriptorDuplex` created here

https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/5906dbfc70760d88fc87a0fa4165efb19020369d/angr/state_plugins/posix.py#L342-L344

But `state.posix.sockets` is pair of `SimPacketsStream` created here

https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/5906dbfc70760d88fc87a0fa4165efb19020369d/angr/state_plugins/posix.py#L333-L338

They will never be the same and `ident` is always `unknown` which should be `('socket', 2, 1, 0, 1)`

title: Code is only loaded from CLE and not from Symbion concrete memory

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body:
If an interesting function in a shared library, I use Symbion to reach it with concrete execution, but after symbolic execution doesn't work because it only looks for code in CLE, and there are only segments from the main executable. So this works only if I load the shared libraries to CLE, but this won't work if the code is generated in the runtime.

Here is the script excerpt (the full one is in the attachment):

```python
avatar_gdb = AvatarGDBConcreteTarget(avatar2.archs.X86_64, "localhost", 3333)
proj = angr.Project("./main", concrete_target=avatar_gdb,
                    use_sim_procedures=True)
entry = proj.factory.entry_state()
entry.options.add(angr.options.SYMBION_SYNC_CLE)
simgr = proj.factory.simgr(entry)
simgr.use_technique(
    angr.exploration_techniques.Symbion(find=[0x7ffff7fc50f9]))
simgr.run()
found = simgr.found[0]
found.block()
```

This crashes in angr/angr/engines/vex/lifter.py:228 with:

```
Exception has occurred: SimEngineError       (note: full exception trace is shown but execution is paused at: _run_module_as_main)
No bytes in memory for block starting at 0x7ffff7fc50f9.
  File "/home/azureuser/angr-dev/angr/angr/engines/vex/lifter.py", line 228, in lift_vex
    raise SimEngineError("No bytes in memory for block starting at %#x." % addr)
  File "/home/azureuser/angr-dev/angr/angr/block.py", line 61, in __init__
    vex = self._vex_engine.lift_vex(
  File "/home/azureuser/angr-dev/angr/angr/factory.py", line 320, in block
    return Block(addr, project=self.project, size=size, byte_string=byte_string, vex=vex,
  File "/home/azureuser/angr-dev/angr/angr/sim_state.py", line 598, in block
    return self.project.factory.block(*args, backup_state=self, **kwargs)
  File "/home/azureuser/ocilab/bugs/run.py", line 24, in <module>
    found.block()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 87, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 97, in _run_module_code
    _run_code(code, mod_globals, init_globals,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 265, in run_path
    return _run_module_code(code, init_globals, run_name,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 87, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 194, in _run_module_as_main (Current frame)
    return _run_code(code, main_globals, None,
```

Before it looked only in CLE for the code where the shared library isn't loaded to.

[env.txt](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/5545508/env.txt)

title: KeyedRegion: Do not crash when storing objects with UnknownSizes.
PagedMemoryMixin changed_bytes incorrect
body:
**Describe the bug.**
`changed_bytes` in `PagedMemoryMixin` reports the page offset, not the actual memory address, in some cases. If an entire page is missing from one memory, the different addresses are properly reported. If both contain the page, however, the return set is populated with the page offset instead of the memory address.

The cause is line 468 in `paged_memory_mixin.py`:

` changes.update(my_page.changed_bytes(other_page, page_addr=pageno * self.page_size))`

The `PagedMemoryMixin` `changed_bytes` is assuming `UltraPage's` `changed_bytes`  returns an absolute address, but it does not.


**Environment Information.**
```
angr environment report
=============================
Date: 2020-10-28 15:20:44.414068
Running in virtual environment at /tmp/angr_temp
Platform: linux-x86_64
Python version: 3.7.9 (default, Aug 18 2020, 02:07:21)
[GCC 9.3.0]
######## angr #########
Python found it in /tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr
Pip version angr 9.0.4663
Couldn't find git info
######## ailment #########
Python found it in /tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ailment
Pip version ailment 9.0.4663
Couldn't find git info
######## cle #########
Python found it in /tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cle
Pip version cle 9.0.4663
Couldn't find git info
######## pyvex #########
Python found it in /tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pyvex
Pip version pyvex 9.0.4663
Couldn't find git info
######## claripy #########
Python found it in /tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/claripy
Pip version claripy 9.0.4663
Couldn't find git info
######## archinfo #########
Python found it in /tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/archinfo
Pip version archinfo 9.0.4663
Couldn't find git info
######## z3 #########
Python found it in /tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/z3
Pip version z3-solver 4.8.9.0
Couldn't find git info
######## unicorn #########
Python found it in /tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/unicorn
Pip version unicorn 1.0.2rc4
Couldn't find git info
######### Native Module Info ##########
angr: <CDLL '/tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/lib/angr_native.so', handle 56069dd5f190 at 0x7f15273ccd50>
unicorn: <CDLL '/tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/unicorn/lib/libunicorn.so', handle 56069d50e300 at 0x7f1526741350>
pyvex: <cffi.api._make_ffi_library.<locals>.FFILibrary object at 0x7f15272ac290>
z3: <CDLL '/tmp/angr_temp/lib/python3.7/site-packages/z3/lib/libz3.so', handle 56069d7237c0 at 0x7f1524a8d050>
```

**To Reproduce.**
```
import angr
import claripy

proj = angr.Project('/bin/ls')
state1 = proj.factory.entry_state()
state2 = proj.factory.entry_state()

# Only one state has the page, all the addresses are correct
state1.memory.store(0x1000000, 0xFF, 1)
print([hex(addr) for addr in state1.memory.changed_bytes(state2.memory)])

# Nothing is changed, no different elements
state2.memory.store(0x1000000, 0xFF, 1)
print([hex(addr) for addr in state1.memory.changed_bytes(state2.memory)])

# The value is different, page offset instead of actual address is returned
state2.memory.store(0x1000000, 0xFE, 1)
print([hex(addr) for addr in state1.memory.changed_bytes(state2.memory)])
```


**Additional context.**
This can be fixed easily by adding `pageno * self.page_size` to each element of the set returned by `PagedMemoryMixin.changed_bytes`, but I'm not sure if the proper fix is to change it there or in `UltraPage`

title: Callgraph contains one erroneous node and edge
body:
**Describe the bug.**

After running `CFGFast`, I obtain a node and an edge in the `project.kb.callgraph` that should not be here:
  * The node is not the start of the function: it's the address of the latest statement of the beginning of the `.plt` section (before the entry of its first function);
  * The edge is between this node, and the first entry in the `.plt`.

Say you have the following:
```asm
;-- section..plt:
;-- .plt:
0x00401020      push    qword [0x00404008] ; [12] -r-x section size 64 named .plt
0x00401026      jmp     qword [0x00404010]
0x0040102c      nop     dword [rax]
;-- int puts (const char *s);
0x00401030      jmp     qword [reloc.puts] ; 0x404018
0x00401036      push    0
0x0040103b      jmp     section..plt
```

Then you would have `0x40102c --> 0x401030` in the callgraph.


**To Reproduce.**

I have observed a similar behavior with several different (dynamically linked) binaries; So I guess any would do...

```python
from angr import Project

project = Project(<ANY BINARY>, auto_load_libs=False)
cfg = project.analyses.CFGFast()

first_plt_function = list(filter(
    lambda f: f.is_plt,
    project.kb.functions.values()
))[0]

predecessor_addresses = list(map(
    lambda p: "%#x" % p,
    project.kb.callgraph.predecessors(first_plt_function.addr)
))

print(predecessor_addresses)
# now, you should see the address in `.plt`, and other places where the first entry is called
```
