title: Unicorn engine now returns the PC after syscall for MIPS.
Depending on how block is lifted, CFGEmulated fails with a SimMemoryError("data not supported")
body:
**Describe the bug.**
CFGEmulated fails with an awkward error. The same test works fine with angr 8.20.7.6.
I have digged into it but I haven't found the root cause and came with even more questions.

The problem arrives when angr tries to find the successors of the following block (the value or r3 @0xc018bec7).
It is either 0xc018bec9 (@0xc018bec3) or [r3, #0x24] (@0xc018bec1) and both values are concrete.

In vex, this is the value or t44 which is evaluated to False (which passes the [isinstance(resolved_tmp, int)](https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/master/angr/analyses/cfg/indirect_jump_resolvers/const_resolver.py#L74) test in const_resolver.py)

```shell
p.factory.block(0xc018beb3).pp()
0xc018beb3:	mov	r8, r5
0xc018beb5:	mvn	r5, #7
0xc018beb9:	ldr	r6, [pc, #0x2f8]
0xc018bebb:	ldr	r7, [sp, #0x2c]
0xc018bebd:	add.w	r3, r6, #0x28
0xc018bec1:	ldr	r3, [r3, #0x24]
0xc018bec3:	cbz	r3, #0xc018bec9
0xc018bec5:	mov	r0, r8
0xc018bec7:	blx	r3
```

**To Reproduce.**
```python
import angr
import traceback

# file is here: https://mega.nz/file/6h4BBLhD#xu6gy5rcwkD8bbJmy5mwaqk_qdsMv22sraMw7HIL4lM
p = angr.Project("vmlinux")
# p.factory.block(0xC018BEB3).vex.pp()  # uncomment this line to make things work (see Additional context)
try:
    p.analyses.CFGEmulated(starts=[0xC018BEB3], call_depth=1)
except:
    traceback.print_exc()

p.factory.block(0xC018BEB3).vex.pp()
```

**Additional context**
The problem only arrives if the block is lifted with py_data (which is what CFG_Emulated does).
If we lift the block **before CFGEmulated** with `p.factory.block` which uses c_data, the block looks like.

```
IRSB {
   t0:Ity_I32 t1:Ity_I32 t2:Ity_I32 t3:Ity_I32 t4:Ity_I32 t5:Ity_I32 t6:Ity_I32 t7:Ity_I32 t8:Ity_I32 t9:Ity_I32 t10:Ity_I32 t11:Ity_I32 t12:Ity_I32 t13:Ity_I32 t14:Ity_I32 t15:Ity_I32 t16:Ity_I32 t17:Ity_I32 t18:Ity_I32 t19:Ity_I32 t20:Ity_I32 t21:Ity_I32 t22:Ity_I32 t23:Ity_I32 t24:Ity_I32 t25:Ity_I32 t26:Ity_I32 t27:Ity_I1 t28:Ity_I32 t29:Ity_I32 t30:Ity_I32 t31:Ity_I32 t32:Ity_I32 t33:Ity_I32 t34:Ity_I32 t35:Ity_I32 t36:Ity_I32 t37:Ity_I32 t38:Ity_I32 t39:Ity_I32 t40:Ity_I32 t41:Ity_I32 t42:Ity_I32 t43:Ity_I32 t44:Ity_I1 t45:Ity_I32 t46:Ity_I32 t47:Ity_I32 t48:Ity_I32 t49:Ity_I32 t50:Ity_I1 t51:Ity_I32 t52:Ity_I32 t53:Ity_I1 t54:Ity_I32 t55:Ity_I32 t56:Ity_I32 t57:Ity_I1 t58:Ity_I32 t59:Ity_I32 t60:Ity_I32 t61:Ity_I1 t62:Ity_I32 t63:Ity_I32 t64:Ity_I1 t65:Ity_I32 t66:Ity_I32 t67:Ity_I32 t68:Ity_I1 t69:Ity_I1 t70:Ity_I1 t71:Ity_I32 t72:Ity_I32 t73:Ity_I32 t74:Ity_I1 t75:Ity_I1 t76:Ity_I1 t77:Ity_I1 t78:Ity_I32 t79:Ity_I32 t80:Ity_I32 t81:Ity_I32

   00 | ------ IMark(0xc018beb2, 2, 1) ------
   01 | t0 = GET:I32(itstate)
   02 | t37 = And32(t0,0x000000f0)
   03 | t36 = Xor32(t37,0x000000e0)
   04 | t38 = GET:I32(cc_op)
   05 | t35 = Or32(t38,t36)
   06 | t39 = GET:I32(cc_dep1)
   07 | t40 = GET:I32(cc_dep2)
   08 | t41 = GET:I32(cc_ndep)
   09 | t42 = armg_calculate_condition(t35,t39,t40,t41):Ity_I32
   10 | t44 = CmpNE32(t37,0x00000000)
   11 | t43 = ITE(t44,t42,0x00000001)
   12 | t6 = GET:I32(r5)
   13 | t49 = GET:I32(r8)
   14 | t50 = CmpNE32(t43,0x00000000)
   15 | t48 = ITE(t50,t6,t49)
   16 | PUT(r8) = t48
   17 | ------ IMark(0xc018beb4, 4, 1) ------
   18 | PUT(r5) = 0xfffffff8
   19 | PUT(pc) = 0xc018beb9
   20 | ------ IMark(0xc018beb8, 2, 1) ------
   21 | t79 = LDle:I32(0xc018c1b4)
   22 | PUT(r6) = t79
   23 | PUT(pc) = 0xc018bebb
   24 | ------ IMark(0xc018beba, 2, 1) ------
   25 | t59 = GET:I32(sp)
   26 | t58 = Add32(t59,0x0000002c)
   27 | t80 = LDle:I32(t58)
   28 | PUT(r7) = t80
   29 | ------ IMark(0xc018bebc, 4, 1) ------
   30 | t21 = Add32(t79,0x00000028)
   31 | PUT(pc) = 0xc018bec1
   32 | ------ IMark(0xc018bec0, 2, 1) ------
   33 | t65 = Add32(t21,0x00000024)
   34 | t81 = LDle:I32(t65)
   35 | PUT(r3) = t81
   36 | PUT(pc) = 0xc018bec3
   37 | ------ IMark(0xc018bec2, 2, 1) ------
   38 | PUT(itstate) = 0x00000000
   39 | t70 = CmpEQ32(t81,0x00000000)
   40 | if (t70) { PUT(pc) = 0xc018bec9; Ijk_Boring }
   41 | ------ IMark(0xc018bec4, 2, 1) ------
   42 | PUT(r0) = t48
   43 | ------ IMark(0xc018bec6, 2, 1) ------
   44 | PUT(itstate) = 0x00000000
   45 | PUT(lr) = 0xc018bec9
   NEXT: PUT(pc) = t81; Ijk_Call
}
```

The block is added to the cache and then this is the block that CFGEmulated would use.
If we start with CFGEmulated, this test in [pyvex/lifting](https://github.com/angr/pyvex/blob/master/pyvex/lifting/__init__.py#L61) will desactivate `allow_arch_optimizations` and create the block which leads to the bug (which is 120 instructions long).

I'm not sure why `allow_arch_optimizations` is deactivated (and my nasty workaround is to let it activated) and in my opinion, this breaks the promise of the block cache (since the cdata vs python memory is not part of the block cache key)

I can provide more info if needed.

title: View constraints which led a state to be unsat

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues that do not require code changes

body:
I was trying to find opaque predicates. This is a basic-block which is an opaque predicate:

```
>>> block.pp()
0x491bc9:       mov     dword ptr [esi + 0x3c], ebx
0x491bcc:       mov     edi, dword ptr [0x590d7c]
0x491bd2:       mov     ebx, dword ptr [0x590d78]
0x491bd8:       mov     eax, edi
0x491bda:       imul    eax, eax
0x491bdd:       imul    eax, eax, 7
0x491be0:       dec     eax
0x491be1:       imul    ebx, ebx
0x491be4:       cmp     eax, ebx
0x491be6:       je      0x491bf5
```

The `cmp eax, ebx` instruction just before the conditional jump will always be false since the condition is `unsat`.

The constraints are:
`eax * eax * 7 - 1 == ebx * ebx`

I am trying to get the constraints using the following snippet:

```py
import angr
import claripy

proj = angr.Project('samples/ac3e087e43be67bdc674747c665b46c2')
block = proj.factory.block(0x00491bc9)

state = proj.factory.blank_state(addr=0x00491bc9)
# state.regs.eax = claripy.BVS('eax', 32)
# state.regs.ebx = claripy.BVS('ebx', 32)

# using save_unsat to store unsat states in unsat stash
# instead of discarding them
simgr = proj.factory.simulation_manager(state, save_unsat=True)

simgr.step()

print(simgr.stashes)

x = simgr.stashes['active'][0]
y = simgr.stashes['unsat'][0]

print(x.solver.constraints)
print(y.solver.constraints)
```

The problem is, I’m getting the same constraints for both the state in the `active` stash as well as the one in the `unsat` stash…

```py
defaultdict(<class 'list'>, {'active': [<SimState @ 0x491be8>], 'stashed': [], 'pruned': [], 'unsat': [<SimState @ 0x491bf5>], 'errored': [], 'deadended': [], 'unconstrained': []})
[<Bool reg_esi_0_32{UNINITIALIZED} + 0x3c <= 0xffffffff>, <Bool reg_esi_0_32{UNINITIALIZED} + 0x3c == 0xffffffff>]
[<Bool reg_esi_0_32{UNINITIALIZED} + 0x3c <= 0xffffffff>, <Bool reg_esi_0_32{UNINITIALIZED} + 0x3c == 0xffffffff>]
```

My question is, how can I get the constraints which caused the `y` state to go into the `unsat` stash?

```
  File "/home/ling/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cffi/api.py", line 362, in from_buffer
    require_writable)
TypeError: expected an array ctype, got 'void *'
```

and I solve it by upgrade cffi from cffi-1.12.2 to cffi-1.14.0.
In the setup.py of angr, the version of cffi is only required >=1.7.0

title: Fixed indirect_jump_resolvers reusing func_addr for ijk_calls to outs…
body:
…ide functions

When updating targets for a resolved indirect_jump in cfg_fast, to_outside
does not consider that an ijk_call is naturally a jump to an outside function
and should be set to True for any ijk_call jumpkind.

title: Typehoon: Infer types of stores to non-constant offsets.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body:
Also fixed the following bugs:

- Subtype relations between actual parameters and formal parameters was
inverted.

- StructuredCodeGen could not properly print non-constant array offsets.

- SimpleSolver could not properly join an Int and a single-field Struct.

title: CFGFast: Fix out-of-bound data load caused by aligning. Fix #2201.
IfSimplifier: Gracefully handle non-constant conditional branch targets.
Fixed Windows state_blank thread handling
body: `state_blank` was not passing `thread_idx` to the super class which was causing the register values to be set for the thread at index 0 instead of the correct index.

<!--

For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*

**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
Hi, I'm trying to migrate the [karonte project](https://github.com/ucsb-seclab/karonte) to angr 8. But CFGFast fails on many binaries from the provided testcase.
This is the test scirpt I used:
```python
import angr
import sys

def test_cfg(path):
    p = angr.Project(path, auto_load_libs=False)
    cfg = p.analyses.CFGFast(show_progressbar=False)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_cfg(sys.argv[1])
```
` /firmware/NETGEAR/analyzed/R7800/firmware/squashfs-root/usr/sbin/uhttpd` and `/firmware/NETGEAR/analyzed/R7800/firmware/squashfs-root/usr/sbin/hostapd` from the karonte testset as examples:

title: DepGraph.transitive_closure: Always include the beginning def node.
Make SimEngineLight._context always return a tuple.
body: It should never return a list.

title: VEXHeavy: Do not add the same guard twice.
body:
The exit guard for the default exit has been previously added when
processing the Exit statement, which adds constraints for both branches.
Adding it again at default exist is redundant.

TODO:
- [ ] Add a test case.

title: Do not pickle the analyses hub with Project.
body:
Otherwise a restored Project instance will not have access to new angr
analyses.

title: RDA: Do not re-initialize ReachingDefinitionState when copying.
ConvenientMappingsMixin should not always create fillers.
body:
ConvenientMappingsMixin conflicts with DefaultFillerMixin in an
unexpected way. Whenever a store() is called, ConvenientMappingsMixin
will attempt to load from the same address and expect a KeyError to be
raised if the content does not exist. However, UltraPage and the
DefaultFillerMixin will always fill in default content and will never
raise a KeyError.

This PR adds a new parameter `fill_missing` to load() and will cause
UltraPage to raise a KeyError when fill_missing is set to False, which
allows memory mixins to bypass the missing-value-filling logic.

body:
Also with the following fixes:

- The base engine in VariableRecoveryFast: Fix how existing variables
are found in _assign_to_register(). This fix addresses conflicts where a
statement touches (reads/writes) more than one variables.

- Decompiling a function no longer removes the already-recovered
variables on VEX code in the knowledge base. Now it always write
varibles that are discovered in AIL to a new variable-kb.

**Describe the bug.**

Sup guys :) I was just playing recent CTF with angr and got this issue:

Here is the script:

```python
import logging
import angr
import claripy

if __name__ == '__main__':

    #logging.getLogger('angr.sim_manager').setLevel('DEBUG')

    proj = angr.Project("./reee")

    LEN = 33 + 1 #5+21+2 
    
    input_chars = claripy.BVS('flag', 8*LEN)
    
    argv = [proj.filename]
    argv.append(input_chars)

    state = proj.factory.full_init_state(args=argv, add_options=angr.options.unicorn, remove_options={angr.options.LAZY_SOLVES})

    prefix = bytes("pctf{".encode("utf-8"))
    for i, char in enumerate(input_chars.chop(bits=8)):

        if i < len(prefix):
            state.add_constraints(char == prefix[i]) 
        if i == LEN - 1:
            state.add_constraints(char == b"\x00") # this may be redundant
        else:
            state.add_constraints(
                char <= claripy.BVV(b'\x7e'), 
                char >= claripy.BVV(b'\x20'))

    print("start: ", state)
    while True:
        succ = state.step()
        if len(succ.successors) == 2:

            print("multiple paths:", succ.successors)
            print("choosing first...")
        
            state1, state2 = succ.successors
            print(state1.solver.eval(input_chars, cast_to=bytes))
            print(state2.solver.eval(input_chars, cast_to=bytes))

            succ.successors[0] = state1
        elif len(succ.successors) == 0:
            break
        elif len(succ.successors) > 2:
            print("more than 2 paths:", succ.successors)
            break

        state = succ.successors[0]
        
    print("done 5 + dump1")
    print(state.posix.dumps(1))
    print(state.solver.eval(input_chars, cast_to=bytes))
```

PS: Just in case you need the correct flag: `pctf{ok_nothing_too_fancy_there!}` and here is the z3 solver:

```python
from z3 import *

targetBytes = "485F36353525142C1D01032D0C6F35617E340A44242C4A4619595B0E787429132C004889C2488955E848837DE800740CBFD1094000E8DBFAFFFF"
targetBytes = bytes().fromhex(targetBytes)
print("targetBytes = %x" % len(targetBytes))

prefix = bytes("pctf{".encode("utf-8"))

for LEN in range(0x6, len(targetBytes)):

    print("trying %d as a length..." % LEN)

    sol = Solver()

    flag0 = [BitVec("%d"%i, 32) for i in range(LEN)]
    

    for i in range(0, len(prefix)):
        sol.add(flag0[i] == prefix[i])
    
    for i in range(len(prefix), LEN):
        sol.add(And([flag0[i] >= 0x20, flag0[i] <= 0x7f]))

    flag = [f for f in flag0]
    
    prevXor = 0x50
    for i in range(0x539):
        for j in range(len(flag)):
            flag[j] = prevXor ^ flag[j]
            prevXor ^= flag[j]

    for i in range(LEN):
        sol.add(flag[i] == targetBytes[i])

    if sol.check() != sat:
        print(":(")
        continue
        
    print(":)")
    m = sol.model()
    
    outFlag = bytearray(0)
    for f in flag0:
        outFlag.append(m[f].as_long())

    print(outFlag)
    break
```

title: VariableAccess: Make it hashable.
body: This commit solves the problem of duplicated VariableAccess instances variable manager for a single variable.

title: FunctionSerializer: Fix a bug with external functions/blocks.
body:
The old implementation will convert all jumpout sites to callout sites
and incorrectly convert all jumpout blocks into functions. This would
create empty functions that should not have been there. This commit
fixes the aforementioned bug.

title: Bug fix: Edge data got wrapped twice during AIL graph conversion.
body:
The bug effectively disabled RegionIdentifier._make_supergraph(), which
led to much more workload in region identification. As a result, fixing
this bug significantly speeds up RegionIdentifier on large functions
with many function calls.

title: VariableRecoveryFast: Do not write to stack if the offset is not a constant.
RegionIdentifier: Recompute endnodes after removing cycles from the graph.
body: With this fix, the decompiled code of `1after909.doit` has no gotos.

title: Deeper copy in `CFGManager`
body:
* its `cfgs` attribute is a dict, which is shallow-copied by default
  * for some reason `copy.deepcopy()` raise a very nebulous error
  * reproduce the dict using the graph's `copy()` method

---

Before this change, this is the behavior I had (when breaking in `CFGManager.copy()`:
```
ipdb> id(self.cfgs)
140222354359952
ipdb> id(cm.cfgs)
140222351599408
ipdb> id(cm.cfgs['CFGFast'].copy())
140222354888272
ipdb> id(self.cfgs['CFGFast'].copy())
140222354888272
```

title: Handle tailcalls when making return edges with detect_tail_calls set
body:
_make_return_edges only checks immediate predecessors for return addrs
when determining successors for return edges. This skips functions
that are tailcalls, as the caller it returns to is by definition
not the immediate predecessor, leading to an inaccurate cfg.

Since tailcall detection is already done under cfg_base, added a set
to track tailcall addrs found when detect_tail_calls is set, so
implementations like cfg_fast can reuse this information.

title: Decompilation improvements 04/12/2020

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body:
- Fix some issues in RegionIdentifier and improve the speed of
structuring large acyclic graphs.

- Remove an unnecessary deep recursive copy of
Region.graph_with_successors in Structurer.

- Fix a bug in Structurer that prevents the structuring of some trivial
if-then-else cases.

- Add a graph walking utility AILGraphWalker.

- Allow optimization passes to rewrite the entire AIL graph.

title: arg_locs: is_fp should also rely on is_fp_arg().
body: So that the logic of generating the `is_fp` list complies with the logic in `ArgSession.next_arg()`.

title: CFGFast: Fix: ud2 on x86 goes undetected. Fixes #1963.
body: Apparently VEX doesn't treat ud2 as part of a block on X86.

title: CFGFast: Fix: Decoding ud2 marks the next two bytes as nodecode.
body:
This is a weird behavior: VEX considers ud2 to be part of a block but
not ud0 or ud1. This behavior may change in the future in VEX, so I also
added a test case in test_vex.py to enforce the behavior.

title: Definition should not take into account its data.
body:
The .data field is just there acting as a handy value storage during
analysis. It has nothing to do with what a definition is.

Also fix a bug in `Dataset.__repr__()`.

title: Unsat conditional exits should not make the parent unsat.
body: `add_successor()` may fail and raise a `SimUnsatError` if the `guard` is not satisfiable. In the case of a conditional exit, this exception will be thrown all the way up to `SimulationManager.step_state()` and will lead to pruning the _parent_ state, regardless of whether the default exit is satisfiable or not. This commit fixes the above bug.

title: Decompilation improvements 03/28/2020.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body:
- Rename DefUseGraph to DepGraph, which is what it should have been.

- Remove dead_virgin_definitions.

- Add all_definitions to ReachingDefinitionsAnalysis. Now dead
assignment elimination can be done properly by finding all definitions
without any uses (instead of using the half-assed dead-virgin
definitions, which does not work correctly in cases where a def is only
used on one path but not the other path).

- Implement propagation count limit to avoid some excessive expression
propagation.

- Add decompilation options.

title: Decompilation improvements 03/27/2020

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Adding a new control knob to something

body:
- Correctly support iterative structuring of loop regions with abnormal
exits (loop regions with abnormal entries are not supported yet).

- Add a few more boolean expression simplification routines.

- Unify the use of claripy ASTs. All claripy ASTs are removed at the
very end of the iterative structuring.

- Support continue statement.

- Refactor the code.

title: Decompilation improvements 03/26/2020

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body: Sync: https://github.com/angr/ailment/pull/40

title: Decompilation improvements 03/25/2020

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body:
- Structurer: Aggressively remove all conditional jumps.

- Structurer: Support merging nesting ifs.

- Multiple bug fixes in Structurer.

title: GraphRegion: Do not generate [None] as self.successors.
CFGBase: Stricter PLT stub removal to avoid wrong removals.
Optimize the O(n!) implementation of RegionIdentifier.slice_graph().
body: I'm surprised that we did not hit this problem until recently. It is now `O(N+E)`.

title: Fix the postdom optimization for acyclic regions.
body:
Always check if the last node in the region is the postdominator for the
entire graph with the region's successors into consideration.

title: Structurer: Support switch-case structures.

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Adding a new control knob to something

body:
Also fixed multiple bugs in Propagator and structurer.

- Propagator will not replace with an expression that has a
sub-expression that has been modified before.
- Structurer will not raise exceptions on indirect jump targets.
- _get_reaching_condition_subexprs() never really supports Or. Fix that.

TODO:

- [x] Split `_make_switch_cases()` into multiple methods.
- [x] Replace all `goto` statements that go to the end of the switch-case structure with `break` statements.
- [x] Test the support of multiple blocks in one case branch.
- [x] Test the support of fall-through blocks in one case (~I'm pretty sure this will either crash or generate gotos~).

title: Decomplation improvements 03/11/2020

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Adding a new control knob to something

title: Structurer: Overwrite the array element before eliminating other elements.
Make angr errors with multiple arguments picklable.
body:
Closes #1986

See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16244923/how-to-make-a-custom-exception-class-with-multiple-init-args-pickleable

title: DominanceFrontier: Speed up graph creation by fixing __hash__().
Fix multiple issues with propagator and its AIL engine.

labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body: Based on https://github.com/angr/angr/pull/1970.

Script:
```python
"""
file: angrBlocks.py
"""
import angr
import logging
import optparse

logging.getLogger('angr.analyses').setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
def dumpBlocks(binary):
    # "force_complete_scan" default is True
    p = angr.Project(binary, load_options={'auto_load_libs': False})
    cfg = p.analyses.CFGFast()

    # iter over the cfg functions
    for func_addr in cfg.functions:
        func = cfg.functions[func_addr]
        print("function %s, its addr is 0x%x" % (func.name, func.addr))
        # iter over blocks
        for bb in func.blocks:
            print("basic block addr 0x%x, its size 0x%x" % (bb.addr, bb.size))
            cfg_node = cfg.get_any_node(bb.addr)
            # bb.instruction_addrs can get the instrction address of block
            if cfg_node != None and bb.size != 0:
                for inst in bb.capstone.insns:
                    inst_va = inst.address
                    print("instruction: 0x%x" % (inst_va))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    parser = optparse.OptionParser()
    parser.add_option("-b", "--binary", dest = "binary", action = "store", type = "string", \
            help = "binary file", default = None)
    (options, args) = parser.parse_args()
    if options.binary == None:
        print("please input the binary file")
        exit(-1)

    dumpBlocks(options.binary)
```

The binary file that trigger the bug is attached. Before disassembling, I strip the binary file firstly.  
[binary with symbol](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/4205202/dwp.zip)

**Additional context.**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

angr's debug log shows that it raise `Decoding error` at `ud2` instruction address, such like:

```
ERROR   | 2020-02-14 10:39:40,059 | ^[[34mangr.analyses.cfg.cfg_fast^[[0m | ^[[34mDecoding error occurred at address 0x809b1f7 of function 0x809b1f0.^[[0m
ERROR   | 2020-02-14 10:39:40,248 | ^[[34mangr.analyses.cfg.cfg_fast^[[0m | ^[[34mDecoding error occurred at address 0x80952c7 of function 0x80952c0.^[[0m
```

Disassembled instruction at `0x809b1f7` is `ud2`:
```
0809b1f0 <_ZN4gold16Elf_reloc_mapperD0Ev>:
 809b1f0:       55                      push   %ebp
 809b1f1:       89 e5                   mov    %esp,%ebp
 809b1f3:       50                      push   %eax
 809b1f4:       8b 45 08                mov    0x8(%ebp),%eax
 809b1f7:       0f 0b                   ud2
 809b1f9:       89 45 fc                mov    %eax,-0x4(%ebp)
 809b1fc:       8d 74 26 00             lea    0x0(%esi,%eiz,1),%esi
```
Same problem at address `0x80952c7`.

title: Fix ordering of node addrs for _libc_start_main
body:
As symbols are identified and processed first, _libc_start_main
can be encountered before the entry node in certian binaries.
this causes the procedure to be run on the wrong entry block addr,
leading to an incorrect parsing of the init/main/fini arguments
and subsequent missing blocks from the generated cfg.

Reordering the starting_points ensures the correct entry addr is
used as the src_node when _lib_start_main procedure is called

title: X86 instruction loop does not end a block with size specified
body:
<!--
*Disclaimer:
The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers.
While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best.
For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*
-->
**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->

When `size` is explicitly specified to `Block()`, the X86 instruction `loop` does not put an end to the current block, which messes the CFG. See 0x4010d3 in the following picture.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5071575/71873602-d30cef00-30dc-11ea-9b39-0cfa11c870a9.png)


**Environment Information.**
<!--
Many common issues are caused by problems with the local Python environment.
Before submitting, double-check that your versions of all modules in the angr suite (angr, cle, pyvex, ...) are up to date.
Please include the output of `python -m angr.misc.bug_report` here.
-->

Latest angr and angr management.

**To Reproduce.**
<!--
Please include *both a script to reproduce the crash, and attach the binary used, if possible*
-->

Decode the basic block 0x4010a2 in binary angr-doc/examples/flareon2015_2/very_success.

**Additional context.**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

The flag `strict_block_end` is lost if `size` is explicitly specified.

title: JumptableResolver: Check if stmt_idx == DEFAULT_STATEMENT before accessing block.statements.
CFGFast: Fix the bug that disabled cc detection. Add a test.
Switch deps tracking to use frozenset instead of tuple. causes less OOM.
Fix a previous optimization in CFGBase that went totally wrong.
body:
- `all_func_addrs` should be sorted. It wasn't since the previous optimization.
- `all_func_addrs` should include all function addresses and is used as a way to detect incorrect function merges. Eliminating `predetermined_function_addrs` from it will essentially disable this sentinel check.

This fix addresses many incorrect CFG recovery issues, especially in ARM binaries.

title: Fix an incorrect jump resolving case in MipsElfFastResolver. Close #1861.
Strange successors of the return block of a function
body:
I'm analysing a MIPS binary when facing the problem.

The problem exists in the funcition `do_ssc`.

In the following block which has a return statement
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8875073/69912053-4fb60900-145f-11ea-9152-4026aab7f033.png)

When I run `node.successors` I got
```
In [103]: end.successors                                                                                              
Out[103]: 
[<CFGNode 0x40a7a8[28]>,
 <CFGNode do_ssc+0x12c [28]>,
 <CFGNode do_ssc+0x4c4 [28]>,
 <CFGNode do_ssc+0x45c [24]>,
 <CFGNode do_ssc+0x2a8 [24]>]
```
Their addresses are `0x40a7a8`, `0x40a33c`, `0x40a6d4` and `0x40a4b8` respectively.

I know the cfg of angr is interfunctional, however, only `0x40a7a8` is an caller of `do_ssc`.

May I know why other threes exist?

title: BasePointerSaveSimplifier: Fix amd64 support.
CFGFast: Resolve indirect jumps before following undetermined pending jobs.
body:
It was assumed in CFGFast that it will determine the returning status of
all (currently discovered) functions before popping a pending job.
However, it is not the case if determining the returning status of the
function will require resolving an indirect jump first, which is the case
in issue #1844.

This commit solves this specific case by making sure indirect jump
resolving happens prior to the unconfirmed pending jobs are popped out
from the PendingJobs queue.

This commit closes issue #1844.

title: CFG contains incorrect nodes/edges after a non returning function
body:
---

**Describe the bug.**

CFGFast generates a node and an edge to that node after a block that calls a function that is known to not return.




**Environment Information.**

This requires https://github.com/fmagin/cle/tree/macho-reloc and https://github.com/fmagin/angr/tree/libobjc to hook the runtime functions and identify `___stack_chk_fail` as non returning


**To Reproduce.**

```python
import angr
import os

# If run from angr-dev folder
# test_location = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)), 'binaries', 'tests')


proj = angr.Project(os.path.join(test_location, 'armhf', 'FileProtection-05.arm64.macho'), load_options={ 'main_opts' : {'gen_relocs': True}})


# normalize doesn't seem to affect this, but is required to make the graph isomorphic to the IDA one in other aspects
cfg = proj.analyses.CFGFast( normalize=True)

# Some function that calls ___stack_chk_fail in one block
f = proj.kb.functions[0x100005528]

# Block that unconditionally calls ___stack_chk_fail
b = f.get_node(0x100005848)


# Confirming that other behaviour works
state = proj.factory.blank_state(addr=0x100005848)

simgr = proj.factory.simgr(state)
# This calls the simproc and terminates the state
simgr.explore()
```

```python
>>>  b.successors()
[<Function sub_1000064b0 (4294993072)>, <BlockNode at 0x10000584c (size 36)>]
>>> b.successors()[0].returning
False
```
I.e. the block has a BlockNode as a successor (that is in fact just the start of the next function, that is also correctly recognized as one as shown by `f = proj.kb.functions[0x10000584c]` ) despite calling a function that is known to not return.

**Additional context.**

There is a chance that messed up something with the relocations and subsequent auto hooking, but given that the stub function `sub_1000064b0` is correctly identified as not returning based on the SimProcedure not returning I would expect this to work.

title: DDG has Underconstrained Dependencies
body:
<!--
*Disclaimer:
The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers.
While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best.
For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*
-->
---

**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
The _stmt_graph of the DDG has incorrect edges.
Consider the following test case.
```c
char c;
void f1(void) {
        c = 'b';
}

int main(void) {
        c = 'a';
        f1();
        int b = c == 'a';
        return 0;
}
```
The `main` function and `f1` function both write to the same global variable `c`.
At the end of the `main` function, the global variable is read from.
We want to get the data dependencies for this statement (this is our target statement).
Since the write in `f1` occurs after the write in `main`, the target statement should only depend on the write in `f1`.
The DDG, however, contains both writing statements as dependencies for the target statement.
This can be seen in the image below.
![ddg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2248306/67516533-a9076d00-f655-11e9-9d57-f3b9622864fd.png)
Here follows the relevant VEX and assembly code of the test case to interpret the image above.
```
FUNCTION: f1
    [f1]
    [f1] BLOCK: 0x401125
...
    [f1] 0x401129:    mov    byte ptr [rip + 0x2ef9], 0x62
...   
    [f1] IRSB:
...
    [f1] 0x401125[009] : ------ IMark(0x401129, 7, 0) ------
    [f1] 0x401125[010] : STle(0x0000000000404029) = 0x62
...
FUNCTION: main
    [main]
    [main] BLOCK: 0x401133 [exit to: f1]
...
    [main] 0x40113b:    mov    byte ptr [rip + 0x2ee7], 0x61
    [main] 0x401142:    call    0x401125
    [main] IRSB:
...
    [main] 0x401133[015] : ------ IMark(0x40113b, 7, 0) ------
    [main] 0x401133[016] : STle(0x0000000000404029) = 0x61
    [main] 0x401133[017] : PUT(rip) = 0x0000000000401142 (offset=184)
...
======
    [main]
    [main] BLOCK: 0x401147
    [main] 0x401147:    movzx    eax, byte ptr [rip + 0x2edb]
    [main] 0x40114e:    cmp    al, 0x61
    [main] 0x401150:    sete    al
...
    [main] IRSB:
    [main] 0x401147[000] : ------ IMark(0x401147, 7, 0) ------
    [main] 0x401147[001] : t13 = LDle:I8(0x0000000000404029)
    [main] 0x401147[002] : t34 = 8Uto32(t13)
    [main] 0x401147[003] : t12 = t34
    [main] 0x401147[004] : t35 = 32Uto64(t12)
    [main] 0x401147[005] : t11 = t35
    [main] 0x401147[006] : PUT(rax) = t11 (offset=16)
 ...
```
The statement `[main] 0x401147[001] : t13 = LDle:I8(0x0000000000404029)` corresponds to the where the global variable is read from in `main`. The statement `[main] 0x401133[016] : STle(0x0000000000404029) = 0x61` correspond to where `'a'` is written to the global variable in `main` and the statement `[f1] 0x401125[010] : STle(0x0000000000404029) = 0x62` corresponds to where `'b'` is written to the global variable in `f1`.
Therefore, only the edge from `0x401125[10] ` to `0x401147[1]` is correct. 


**Environment Information.**
<!--
Many common issues are caused by problems with the local Python environment.
Before submitting, double-check that your versions of all modules in the angr suite (angr, cle, pyvex, ...) are up to date.
Please include the output of `python -m angr.misc.bug_report` here.
-->

title: Fix symbolic operand relocation logging.
body:
Relocations for symbolic operands were not created at the right
address. E.g. jumps would record a relocation at +1 offset which is
not always correct.  The fix uses capstone information about the
immediate and displacement offsets to compute the right relocation addresses.

When I tried to get all of the callsites for a function, I found that part of the callsite was missing and that the base block was divided into a wrong function.

After debugging, I found that the target address was not obtained in the right way when the branch condition in the backward slice.

``` python
        # function resolve line 95
```

title: TracerDesyncError: Address mismatch during single-stepping
body:
I've been trying to use tracer on CROMU_00030 (a CGC sample) to dynamically execute the trace generated by the provided pov input. 
The sample can be found here https://github.com/CyberGrandChallenge/samples/tree/master/cqe-challenges/CROMU_00030

This is the code I'm using:
```
import tracer

from angr.exploration_techniques.tracer import TracingMode

target = "/root/cgc/CROMU_00030/bin/CROMU_00030"

accepted_inp = "/root/cgc/CROMU_00030/pov/POV_00000.xml"

t = tracer.Tracer(binary=target, pov_file=accepted_inp, mode=TracingMode.Permissive, copy_states=True)

t.simgr.run()
```

Without `mode=TracingMode.Permissive` it throws the following error:
`angr.exploration_techniques.tracer.TracerDesyncError: Oops! angr did not follow the trace`

While by adding this mode, the error changes to:
`angr.exploration_techniques.tracer.TracerDesyncError: Address mismatch during single-stepping.`

To make tracer.py correctly parse an xml pov file I added the following line to https://github.com/angr/tracer/blob/master/tracer/tracer.py#L80
-> `s.preconstrainer.preconstrain_file(input.writes, s.posix.stdin, True)`
making it preconstrain `input.writes` in case the input is a pov_file, `input` otherwise.

I'm using the updated version of angr-dev.

Do you know how to solve this issue?

I've attached [CROMU30.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/3601382/CROMU30.zip)
which contains the binary, the script and POV_00000.xml.

Thank you in advance!

title: CFGEmulated with multiple starts
body:
I've been using CFGEmulated as I need to trace control flow via things like function pointers.  It works well for most of the program except it misses control flow from the .fini section that is called by the local runtime.  This is expected as it is not directly referenced from the main program.  I tried adding the fini address as an additional value in 'starts' but the results don't seem to work.

With starts = [project.entry]:  
   regular program CFG
With starts = [.fini address]
   CFG from the .fini function
With both project.entry and fini addresses:
   the correct CFG for the last value in the list,  nothing for the first value

In the case of starts=[fini address, project.entry], the fini function is included but the CFG nodes are actually addresses at the project.entry location.  It seems like the latter is overwriting data from the former.

My script:
```python
import angr
import os
import nose


def main():
    proj = angr.Project('test', auto_load_libs=False)
    cfg = proj.analyses.CFGEmulated(context_sensitivity_level=2, keep_state=True, state_add_options=angr.sim_options.refs)
    ddg = proj.analyses.DDG(cfg)

    for node in ddg._data_graph.nodes():
        if isinstance(node.variable, angr.sim_variable.SimMemoryVariable):
            nose.tools.assert_greater_equal(node.variable.addr, 0, msg="Variable {} has an negative address: {}".format(node.variable, node.variable.addr))

if __name__ == "__main__":
        main()
```

title: TypeBackend converts expression into a boolean instead of TypedValue and other quirks
body:
---

**Describe the bug.**

Various weird unexpected results of `TypeBackend.convert`



Sane, though arguably that could be `SimTypeBool` instead of `TOP` ?:
`bt.convert(untyped_int_a == untyped_int_a)` => `TypedValue(TOP, <Bool True>)`

Unexpected return type `Bool` instead of `TypedValue` 
`bt.convert(typed_int_a == typed_int_a)` => `True`

Unexpected return type `Bool` that also is not what the expression evaluates too when simplified:
`e = typed_int_a == untyped_int_a`
`claripy.simplify(e)` => `<Bool True>`
`bt.convert(e)` => `False`


**Environment Information.**

Probably not an environment issue.


**To Reproduce.**


Setup:
```python
import claripy
import angr
from angr.sim_type import *
bt = angr.type_backend.TypeBackend()
from angr.type_backend import TypedValue, TypeAnnotation

typed_int_a = claripy.BVV(1, 8).annotate(TypeAnnotation(SimTypeInt(label=[])))
typed_int_b = claripy.BVV(2, 8).annotate(TypeAnnotation(SimTypeInt(label=[])))

untyped_int_a = claripy.BVV(1, 8)
untyped_int_b = claripy.BVV(2, 8)

```

title: CFBlanket: Ignore sections that do not occupy memory.
CFGEmulated: Fix .resume(). Add a test case.
Weird PowerPC ABI not being handled
body:
**Describe the bug.**

If generating an entry state with arguments, the arguments and argc are not set up as expected by the program by the time it reaches main. They are in r3 and r4 in the `entry_state`, and should be in r3 and r4 when reaching `main`, but for example the argv pointer get's overwritten at `0x100004d8` in `start` without ever being read.


**Environment Information.**

Pretty sure this is not an environment issue.


**To Reproduce.**

To actually ever reach main (another indication of a general other weird ABI) https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/2dbc711baf82cd59c21a382e9605f47f3db743eb/angr/procedures/glibc/__libc_start_main.py#L197-L208 has to be commented out, otherwise the SimProcedure just produces one unconstrained successor. When commented out it seems like the initializers are correctly run and main is reached (albeit with incorrect arguments set)

The loader issue ( https://github.com/angr/cle/issues/142 ) has to be fixed so the SimProcs actually work, so the hooks do that manually:

```python
import angr
import claripy

proj = angr.Project("./PowerToThePeople", load_options={'auto_load_libs': False})
# Generated from ghidra
f_list = [(0x10010b64, 'putchar'),
 (0x10010b74, 'memcpy'),
 (0x10010b84, 'strncpy'),
 (0x10010b94, 'memset'),
 (0x10010b9c, 'sprintf'),
 (0x10010ba4, 'exit'),
 (0x10010bac, 'atoi'),
 (0x10010bb4, 'strlen'),
 (0x10011000, 'putchar'),
 (0x10011008, 'memcpy'),
 (0x10011014, 'strncpy'),
 (0x10011020, 'memset'),
 (0x10011024, 'sprintf'),
 (0x10011028, 'exit'),
 (0x1001102c, 'atoi'),
 (0x10011030, 'strlen')]

[ proj.hook(addr, angr.SIM_LIBRARIES['libc.so.6'].get(fname, proj.arch), replace=True) for addr, fname in f_list]

proj.hook(0x10010b6c, angr.SIM_LIBRARIES['libc.so.6'].get("__register_frame_info", proj.arch), replace=True)

start_main = angr.SIM_LIBRARIES['libc.so.6'].get("__libc_start_main", proj.arch)

proj.hook(0x10010b8c,start_main, proj.arch, replace=True)

argv1 = claripy.BVS('argv1', 8*9)
argc = claripy.BVS('argc', 4*8)
state = proj.factory.entry_state(args=[proj.filename, argv1], argc=argc)

# If you have angrcli (it's on pip!), this could make debugging a lot easier
import angrcli.plugins.ContextView
from angrcli.interaction.explore import ExploreInteractive
e = ExploreInteractive(proj, state)

# Step through
e.cmdloop()
```
Tarball with binary and the above script:
[PowerToThePeople.tar.gz](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/3435842/PowerToThePeople.tar.gz)





**Additional context.**
This is technically a RE challenge, so it could be assumed this is intentionally broken, but I contacted the author (mr.un1k0d3r) who told me

> I wrote the code in standard c and used uclibc toolchain to compile 

, i.e. this is probably not intentional.

I couldn't get the uclibc toolchain to bootstrap me a toolchain so I could compile PowerPC binary that could serve as a minimal PoC

title: CFGEmulated: Allow resuming without having starts.
Add elf-header to MemoryDataSort. Closes angr/angr-management#107.
CFGFast: Occupy jump tables. Closes #1671.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

title: Fix issues in ForwardAnalysis and StackPointerTracker.
body:
- Input states should not be removed after retrieving, otherwise input
  state merging will not happen.
- ForwardAnalysis now supports fixed point detection after state merging.
- StackPointerTracker now performs fixed point detection after state merging instead of right after executing a node.

This PR closes #1665.

title: add project.filename as part of cfg_key for cfg_cache
body:
Veritesting analyses in angr uses `cfg_cache` to save the cfg it generated before. 

But the `cfg_key` only consists of `addr` and `jumpkind`, without the project filename. It would mistakenly hit `cfg_cache` when we analyze several projects very similar to each others in sequence ( i.e.,  a binary without security patch and its patched version). 

Adding `project.filename` to `cfg_key` would fix the problem.

title: CFGEmulated: Create a fake-ret successor if the indirect jump is a call.
`factory.call_state` reverses symbolic char* arguments
body:
Passing a symbolic bitvector as a `char*` argument to `factory.call_state` reverses the resulting string.  This doesn't happen with string literals or if `SimTypeString` is used instead of `char*`.  `factory.entry_state` also orients its arguments correctly.

Related: #570

**Environment Information.**
```

pyvex: <cffi.api._make_ffi_library.<locals>.FFILibrary object at 0x75eb648231d0>
```

**To Reproduce.**
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import angr
import angr.sim_type as T
import claripy

p = angr.Project('test')

conv_charptr = p.factory.cc(func_ty=T.SimTypeFunction(
        args=[T.parse_type('char*')],
        returnty=T.parse_type('int')))

conv_string = p.factory.cc(func_ty=T.SimTypeFunction(
        args=[T.SimTypeString()],
        returnty=T.parse_type('int')))

print('symbolic vectors')

guess_chars = [claripy.BVS('guess_{}'.format(i), 8) for i in range(17)]
guess = claripy.Concat(*guess_chars)

st_entry = p.factory.entry_state(args=['./test', guess])
st_charptr = p.factory.call_state(0x400700, guess, cc=conv_charptr)
st_string = p.factory.call_state(0x400700, guess, cc=conv_string)

def explore(st):
    sm = p.factory.simulation_manager(st)
    sm.explore(find=0x400736)
    return sm

def solve(st):
    sm = explore(st)
    for f in sm.found:
        return f.solver.eval(guess, cast_to=bytes)

print('entry_state: {}'.format(solve(st_entry)))          # ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP
print('call_state (char*): {}'.format(solve(st_charptr))) # PONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
print('call_state (string): {}'.format(solve(st_string))) # ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP
print()


# On the other hand, string literals never get reversed.

print('string literals')

passwd = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP"

st_l_entry = p.factory.entry_state(args=['./test', passwd])
st_l_charptr = p.factory.call_state(0x400700, passwd, cc=conv_charptr)
st_l_string = p.factory.call_state(0x400700, passwd, cc=conv_string)

print('entry_state: {}'.format(explore(st_l_entry)))          # 1 found
print('call_state (char*): {}'.format(explore(st_l_charptr))) # 1 found
print('call_state (string): {}'.format(explore(st_l_string))) # 1 found
```

```C
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

const char passwd[17] = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP";

int f(char *x) { // 0x400700
  if (strcmp(x, passwd) == 0) {
    printf("correct: %s\n", x); // 0x400736
    return 0;
  }
  else {
    printf("wrong: %s\n", x);
    return 1;
  }
}

int main(int argc, char **argv) {
  if (argc < 2) {
    printf("usage: %s [x]\n", argv[0]);
    return 1;
  }

  return f(argv[1]);
}
```

[Zipped binary](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/3352910/test.zip)

title: calloc: set final_size correctly
body: The maximum size of memory allocated by calloc was always equal to plugin.max_variable_size (apparently 128 bytes), changed it to only when args are symbolic.

title: XRefs: Support getting xrefs to regions, and other fixes

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body:
~~This PR adds two kinda-related things:~~

Some of this was already merged, the remainder is:

~~* When we make a Read Xref, check that the thing we would have read is also a pointer.  If it is, add an Offset to that.~~
* Add the ability to get xrefs to a region.  You probably want that when you're looking for all these offset pointers that could be structs or functions or IO or whatever.
* Ignore NamedRegions when building the CFG

~~...and the usual basket of misc fixes.~~

title: Reassembler: Raise an exception on an unexpected path to avoid undefined variable exceptions in rare cases.
body: https://github.com/angr/angr/issues/1625 is such a case. Although I couldn't reproduce the issue, I definitely see why that could happen. With this fix, it will at least display a proper warning instead of throwing a random crash.

title: Propagator: Return TOP for uninitialized variables.
Backward Slice Statement Dependent on Nonexistent Tmp
body:
**Describe the bug.**
When executing a backward slice with the `Slicecutor`, the engine may encounter a temporary variable whose definition is not included in the backward slice. This leads to an error and causes the symbolic execution to stop.

**Environment Information.**
Here follows the output from: `python -m angr.misc.bug_report`
```

######## unicorn #########
Python found it in /home/user/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/unicorn
Pip version unicorn 1.0.1
Couldn't find git info
######### Native Module Info ##########
angr: <CDLL '/home/user/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/angr/lib/angr_native.so', handle 38c6870 at 0x7f1d5236fdd8>
unicorn: <CDLL '/home/user/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/unicorn/lib/libunicorn.so', handle 2c99390 at 0x7f1d512dd128>
pyvex: <cffi.api._make_ffi_library.<locals>.FFILibrary object at 0x7f1d522c3d68>
z3: <CDLL '/home/user/.virtualenvs/angr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/z3/lib/libz3.so', handle 3cf8ac0 at 0x7f1d1af02ef0>
```


**To Reproduce.**
My script:
```python
import angr
import nose

def main():
    proj = angr.Project("test", auto_load_libs=False)
    cfg = proj.analyses.CFGEmulated(context_sensitivity_level=2, keep_state=True, normalize=True, state_add_options=angr.sim_options.refs)

    main_func = cfg.functions.function(name='main')
    main_node = cfg.model.get_any_node(addr=main_func.addr)
    target_func = cfg.functions.function(name='f_target')
    target_call_site = get_call_site(main_func, target_func)
    target_call_node = cfg.model.get_any_node(addr=target_call_site)
    target_call_block = target_call_node.block

    # Backward slice
    cdg = proj.analyses.CDG(cfg, start=main_func.addr)
    ddg = proj.analyses.DDG(cfg, start=main_func.addr)
    bs_targets = []
    for stmt_idx in range(len(target_call_block.vex.statements)):
        bs_targets.append((target_call_node, stmt_idx)) # Every statement in the call site
    bs = proj.analyses.BackwardSlice(cfg, cdg=cdg, ddg=ddg, targets=bs_targets)
    acfg = bs.annotated_cfg()
    #print(bs.dbg_repr())

    # Symbolic execution
    start_state = proj.factory.blank_state(addr=main_func.addr)
    # Confirm we are actually starting in a state with whitelisted statements.
    assert (acfg.get_whitelisted_statements(addr=start_state.addr) == None or len(acfg.get_whitelisted_statements(addr=start_state.addr)) > 0)

    simgr = proj.factory.simgr(start_state)
    slicecutor = angr.exploration_techniques.Slicecutor(acfg)
    simgr.use_technique(slicecutor)
    simgr.explore(find=target_call_site)
    for errored in simgr.errored:
        error = errored.error
        nose.tools.assert_not_regex(str(error), r'VEX temp variable \d+ does not exist.', msg="Occurred at: block: 0x{:x}, stmt_idx: {}".format(error.bbl_addr, error.stmt_idx))

def get_call_site(caller_func, callee_func):
    for call_site_addr in caller_func.get_call_sites():
        if caller_func.get_call_target(call_site_addr) == callee_func.addr:
            return call_site_addr
    return None

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

Source code:
```c
// compile with: gcc -O0 -o test test.c
#include <stdio.h>

void f_target(char buf[]) {
    printf("f_target: %s\n", buf);
}

void f2(char buf[]) {
    buf[0] = 'a';
    buf[1] = '\0';
}

int main(void) {
    char buf[8];
    f2(buf);
    f_target(buf);
    return 0;
}
```
Output:
```
AssertionError: Regex matched: 'VEX temp variable 13 does not exist.' matches 'VEX temp variable \\d+ does not exist.' in 'VEX temp variable 13 does not exist. This is usually the result of an incorrect slicing.' : Occurred at: block: 0x4006d1, stmt_idx: 47
```

Here are my files:
[files.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/3326918/files.zip)

Below is the part of the backward slice referred to in the error message.
It can be seen that the definition of temporary variable `t13` at statement index 42 is indeed not included in the backward slice.

**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
I'm getting the "local variable 'label' referenced before assignment after using the ramblr analysis on an arbitrary binary (in my case, the "Hello World")


**Environment Information.**
<!--
Many common issues are caused by problems with the local Python environment.
Before submitting, double-check that your versions of all modules in the angr suite (angr, cle, pyvex, ...) are up to date.
Please include the output of `python -m angr.misc.bug_report` here.
-->

The environment is Ubuntu 16.04 LTS and everything is set up from the angr-dev repo (using the virtualenv). I am able to work out the other test examples from the test_reassembler.py (such as test_exp_gpp(), etc) and was able to obtain the necessary patched binary along with the assembler .s files


**To Reproduce.**
<!--
Please include *both a script to reproduce the crash, and attach the binary used, if possible*
-->
Hello.c
`#include <stdio.h>`

`char* string = "Hello World!\n"; `
`printf("%s", string); `
`return 0: }`

compiled with vanilla Clang

`r = p.analyses.Reassembler(syntax="intel")`

r.assembly is where the error occurs, I have attached the image to showcase this.

title: Protobuf Package Definitions
body:
<!--
*Disclaimer:
The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers.
While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best.
For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*
-->
---

**Describe the bug.**
<!--
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
The protobufs packages and imports are mismatched.

For example, `primitives.proto` is `package angr.protos` but `cfg.proto` imports it as `protos/primitives.proto`. It should be imported as `angr/protos/primitives.proto` instead. You'd have to update your `protoc` includes in the build process to fix this. We've worked around it for now but this can limit the ability to share/use the CFG externally.

If the package and imports both begin with `"angr"` then, in theory, an external build can simply include angr's protos and the generated Python imports would be `from angr.protos import cfg_pb2` rather than `from protos import cfg_pb2`.

**Additional context.**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

See https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/issues/4176. 

Currently, my proto does `import "protos/cfg.proto"` and I pass `-I mydir/angr` to `protoc`, where `mydir/angr/protos/` contains all the proto from here (duplicates due to #1561). The generated Python import is `from protos import cfg_pb2`, which needs to be changed to `from .angr.protos import cfg_pb2` (relative since we keep duplicates so the build system doesn't need angr). This is the only way to keep the messages compatible. If I fix my proto import to use the correct package with `import "angr/protos/cfg.proto"`, the Python code is generated correctly but now the protobuf library itself fails to recognize the CFG message.

title: Solver taking increasingly longer to evaluate a single byte of symbolic memory as global constraint count increases

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues that do not require code changes

body:
Angr version 8.19.4.5
-------

I'm not convinced this is a bug, but it certainly is interesting behavior. I was trying to solve a CTF challenge that had approximately 88k basic blocks where each block would check one byte of the input buffer for correctness. The operation in each block is a simple one, where the shown CONST values change in each block: 

```
if(RANDOM_CONST0 == mem[i] ^ RANDOM_CONST1){
    goto next_basic_block;
}else{
    exiting_function()    //no return
}
```

For brevity's sake I'll just cut to the end where I countered lots of memory issues by writing a script that used `SimulationManager.step()`, manually dropped unwanted states, and manually evaluated each byte of the solution as I went. Following the evaluation I would also concretize the solved-for index of the input buffer by setting it to zero (this seemed to save _a lot_ of memory). 

At first I was getting roughly 21 bytes/s as angr symbolically stepped through each basic block. After a few hundred solves that number dwindled to about 10. After about 65k (there are approximately 88k in total) solved bytes I was getting only 0.33 bytes/s. At this point the script had also consumed about 5GB of RAM and taken 19 hours.

I was speaking with someone on the Slack channel and it seems that perhaps the following snippet of code exhibits the same degrading solving time that I was seeing:

```
s = p.factory.blank_state()
buf = claripy.BVS('large-buffer', 100000*8)
for i,b in enumerate(buf.chop()):
    s.add_constraints(b==(i%255))
a_byte = buf.get_byte(99999)
s.add_constraints(a_byte > 100, a_byte < 200)
s.solver.eval(a_byte)
```

On my machine it took 158 seconds to apply the constraints (2.5GB of RAM) and the `eval` step chugged along for a few minutes before being killed due to an out-of-memory condition. This test-case is very similar to the CTF I was working on, with the only difference being that my script was adding constraints with each basic block instead of adding a large number of them upfront. 

* If we are solving for only a single byte value, why does the time-to-solve seem proportionally related to the number of constraints added to other indicies of the buffer?

---------

For other references: 
[The CTF binary](http://s000.tinyupload.com/?file_id=88399206211278650157)

My solution maintains a single `active` state while using `SimulationManager.step()` to move through each basic block. I manually drop the bad states and evaluate a single byte of the solution at each step. There are three sizes of basic blocks in the binary (0x2d, 0x2f, and 0x30). I determine we made it to a "good" RIP by checking that we offset from the last basic block byte one of those values. Otherwise the state represents one that will eventually call the `badboy` function and exit.
```
#!/usr/bin/env python

import logging
import claripy
import angr
import monkeyhex

import time
import signal
import os
import IPython

def go():
    print('* Loading binary ...')
    
    p = angr.Project('ch30.bin')
    options = {
        angr.options.SYMBOL_FILL_UNCONSTRAINED_MEMORY,
        angr.options.ZERO_FILL_UNCONSTRAINED_REGISTERS,
        angr.options.DOWNSIZE_Z3,
        angr.options.SIMPLIFY_MEMORY_READS,
        angr.options.SIMPLIFY_MEMORY_WRITES
    }

    check_func = p.loader.find_symbol('check').rebased_addr
    badboy_func = p.loader.find_symbol('badboy').rebased_addr
    
    buf_addr = 0x100000
    init_state = p.factory.call_state(check_func, buf_addr, add_options=options, remove_options={angr.options.LAZY_SOLVES})
    sm = p.factory.simulation_manager(init_state)

    print('* Executing ...')

    # The first basic-block does not follow the same predicted sizes as the others,
    # so bootstrap the loop by manually finding a path to get us to the second block
    sm.explore(find=0x400b03, avoid=badboy_func)
    sm.drop(stash='avoid') \
            .drop(stash='deadended') \
            .drop(stash='active') \
            .unstash(from_stash='found', to_stash='active')

    with open('base64_encode.txt', 'w+') as f:
        # We start at 1 and manually write the first solved byte because we bootstrapped
        # the loop through the first basicblock
        buffer_len = 1
        f.write('T')
        prev_time = time.time()

        while(1):
            if(len(sm.active) != 1):
                print('Oops! len(sm.active) != 1')
                IPython.embed()

            rip_before = sm.active[0].solver.eval(sm.active[0].regs.rip)
            sm.active[0].simplify()
            sm.active[0].history.trim()
            sm.step()

            # Each basic-block is 0x2d, 0x2f, or 0x30 bytes in length
            # We only want to keep the states that have reached the next basic-block
            # and are not going down the path to call badboy. We can determine this
            # by checking that the RIP of the state is either 0z2d, 0x2f, or 0x30 bytes
            # ahead of the last basic-block reference
            for a in sm.active:
                rip_after = a.solver.eval(a.regs.rip)
                if (rip_after - rip_before) in (0x2d, 0x2f, 0x30):
                    f.write(chr(a.solver.eval(a.memory.load(buf_addr + buffer_len, 1))))
                    f.flush()

                    # Try to keep memory requirements low by setting memory to concrete
                    a.mem[buf_addr + buffer_len].uint8_t = 0

                    # Bookkeeping
                    buffer_len = buffer_len + 1
                    curr_time = time.time()
                    print('\r0x{:08x}/0x{:08x}, {:2.1f} bytes/s'.format(buffer_len, 88000, 1.0/(curr_time - prev_time)), end='')
                    prev_time = curr_time;
                else:
                    sm.active.remove(a)

            # Special case where we found the final basic-block; break
            if( (0x400000 + 0x3ec2b5) == sm.active[0].solver.eval(sm.active[0].regs.rip) ):
                break

if __name__ == '__main__':
#    logging.getLogger('angr.sim_manager').setLevel('DEBUG')
    go()
```

-------

Other questions about this solution:

* Why is so much memory being consumed? How can I prevent it?
    * I tried concretizing the symbolic memory after evaluating and that seemed to help somewhat
    * The only symbolic reference at each basic block is EAX once its reads in from the symbolic buffer. Everything else is concrete
    * Is the state getting too large? Each basic block is decoupled from the previous, save for the index value to evaluate in that block

title: TypeError: run_initializer() takes 1 positional argument but 6 were given
body:
I have this very simple C program with a buffer overflow on the stack:

```c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {
    char buf[32];
    strcpy(buf,argv[1]);
    printf("Input:%s\n",buf);
    return 0;
}
```

I compiled it using `gcc -g -fno-stack-protector -z execstack -o csbo csbo.c`. Now I have the following code in angr:

```python

def main():

    # Tell angr to go through strcpy
    proj = angr.Project("./csbo", exclude_sim_procedures_list=["strcpy"])

    options = {
        angr.options.SYMBOL_FILL_UNCONSTRAINED_MEMORY,
        angr.options.SYMBOL_FILL_UNCONSTRAINED_REGISTERS,
        angr.options.CONSTRAINT_TRACKING_IN_SOLVER
    }
    options.update(angr.options.unicorn)
    state = proj.factory.entry_state(
        add_options=options,
        remove_options={
            angr.options.LAZY_SOLVES,
            angr.options.SYMBOLIC_MEMORY_NO_SINGLEVALUE_OPTIMIZATIONS
        }
    )

    # We're looking for unconstrained paths
    sm = proj.factory.simulation_manager(state, save_unconstrained=True)

    # Step execution until we find unconstrained paths
    while sm.active and not sm.unconstrained:
        sm.step()

    print(sm)

    # Make a copy of the state
    if not sm.unconstrained:
        raise Exception("Uh oh! Did not find any unconstrained paths!")
    s = sm.unconstrained[0].copy()

    print(s)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

In the logs I can see that it encounters unconstrained paths. After some time, it fails with the following trace:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "solve2.py", line 49, in <module>
    main()
  File "solve2.py", line 36, in main
    sm.step()
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/sim_manager.py", line 343, in step
    successors = self.step_state(state, successor_func=successor_func, **run_args)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/sim_manager.py", line 381, in step_state
    successors = self.successors(state, successor_func=successor_func, **run_args)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/sim_manager.py", line 420, in successors
    return self._project.factory.successors(state, **run_args)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/factory.py", line 54, in successors
    return self.project.engines.successors(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/engines/hub.py", line 128, in successors
    r = engine.process(state, **kwargs)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/engines/hook.py", line 55, in process
    return self.project.factory.procedure_engine.process(state, procedure, force_addr=force_addr, **kwargs)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/engines/procedure.py", line 31, in process
    force_addr=force_addr)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/engines/engine.py", line 60, in process
    self._process(new_state, successors, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/engines/procedure.py", line 65, in _process
    inst = procedure.execute(state, successors, ret_to=ret_to)
  File "/home/vivin/Projects/rampage/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/angr/sim_procedure.py", line 182, in execute
    r = getattr(inst, inst.run_func)(*sim_args, **inst.kwargs)
TypeError: run_initializer() takes 1 positional argument but 6 were given
```
The binary takes in a command-line argument, but I have not specified it as symbolic. I was just curious to see how angr would behave in this situation; specifically whether it could tell that the unconstrained paths could be caused by the command-line argument. I'm not sure if that's the reason for this particular error or not.

title: SimEngineUnicorn: Handle SimValueErrors raised in unicorn.setup().
Tracer: retsite_addr should stay as a state address.
AnnotatedCFG: get_last_statement_index() should check if the default exit is taken.

This bug was introduced in the last refactor where the default statement index
changed from "default" to -2. Thanks @conand for reporting this issue.

title: Unicorn: Always re-create the uc object on MIPS32.
body:
This helps prevent weird bugs in unicorn engine, e.g., reporting having
stepped 1 step while in fact it did not step forward at all.

title: Fix proto message enum reference
body: Forgot the `.CodeReference` when referencing the `enum` types.

title: Fix a panic in libvex caused by passing wrong values to typeOfPrimop().
body:
We should pass enums_to_ints[expr.op] to typeOfPrimop() instead of
enums_to_ints[expr.tag].

This bug was causing a vpanic in libvex whenever angr saw an unsupported VEX operation.

title: strtol: Correctly convert 11-digit numbers.
body:
_string_to_int() did not trigger the cutoff handling logic if the length
of the string equals to state.libc.max_strtol_len, which was causing
issues when converting strings that were exactly 11 bytes long.

title: SimSystemPosix: Call set_state() on self.sockets.
When the tracer finds a crash it does not change the predecessors whi…
body: …ch causes the state to be two states ahead of the previous state. The fix we decided on is to tick the state when we detect a crash.

title: SimAbstractMemory: _load() should not return None upon address concretization failures.
body: Thanks @subwire for reporting this issue.

title: Fix for incorrect condition to filter out ARM plt entries
body:
Hi Guys!

It seems that commit 

https://github.com/angr/angr/commit/1095ed18cc97e50e8c420b4b3c33b0250a427609#diff-3e214ce41c00cfb8a1b7298cd8b39453

inverted condition for removing PLT entries check. For ARM, PLT entries not aligned at 16 bytes should **NOT** be removed.

title: Claripy Annotations being dropped
body:
*Disclaimer: The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers. While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best. For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*

---

**Describe the bug**
I'm filing this bug on angr, although it may actually be a bug in claripy, I'm not sure.  My reproduction case is in angr, so I'll start here.

1. Create an annotated BVS.
2. Do some simple math on the BVS (by executing a single irsb).
3. What comes back is an AST describing the operation(s).
Expected behavior: the final AST includes the annotated BVS, or at least includes the annotation somewhere
Observed behavior: none of the leaves of the AST, nor the AST itself, are annotated. It is as though the original BVS was copied for use in the final AST, and the annotation was dropped.

**Environment Information**
Many common issues are caused by problems with the local Python environment.
Before submitting, double-check that your versions of all modules in the angr suite (angr, cle, pyvex, ...) are up to date.
Please include the output of `python -m angr.misc.bug_report` here.

I reproduced this bug (exactly the same output of the script) in two different environments: one environment is a Mac with my own checkouts of `master` (or nearly so) for `angr`, `claripy`, `pyvex`, `archinfo`, and `cle`, while using Pip for the other dependencies; and the other environment is a Linux machine with `angr 8.19.2.4` and all its dependencies from Pip.  So I don't think the issue is a detail of my environment.  I've included more complete environment descriptions at the bottom just in case.

**To Reproduce**
Please include *both a script to reproduce the crash, and attach the binary used, if possible*

Script to reproduce the problem:
```
import angr
import claripy

def printAst(ast):
    aststr = str(ast)
    annotstr = "(annotated)" if ast.annotations else "(unannotated)"
    print(aststr + " " + annotstr)

def printAstWithLeaves(ast):
    printAst(ast)
    for l in ast.leaf_asts():
        print("    ", end="")
        printAst(l)

proj = angr.Project('simple')
arg = claripy.BVS('arg', 64, annotations=(claripy.Annotation(),))
funcaddr = proj.loader.find_symbol('foo').rebased_addr
state = proj.factory.call_state(funcaddr, arg)
simgr = proj.factory.simgr(state)

print("function argument:")
printAstWithLeaves(arg)
simgr.step()
print("function return value:")
printAstWithLeaves(simgr.active[0].regs.rax)
```

Observed output:
```
function argument:
<BV64 arg_0_64> (annotated)
    <BV64 arg_0_64> (annotated)
function return value:
<BV64 0x0 .. (arg_0_64[28:0] .. 0 + (0xffffffff * arg_0_64[31:0]))> (unannotated)
    <BV64 arg_0_64> (unannotated)
    <BV32 0xffffffff> (unannotated)
    <BV3 0> (unannotated)
    <BV32 0x0> (unannotated)
```

Binary is attached at [simple.gz](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/3036476/simple.gz) (GitHub seems not to allow attaching binaries, so I gzipped the binary)

Binary was acquired by compiling the following source file with `clang -O1` on a Linux machine:
```
int foo(int x) {
    int y = x * 7;
    return y;
}

int main() {
    int x = foo(3);
    return 0;
}
```

**Additional context**
This behavior is _not_ due to the `eliminatable` or `relocatable` properties of the particular `Annotation` object.  I get exactly the same results when adding this annotation instead of a base `claripy.Annotation`:
```
class MyAnnotation(claripy.Annotation):
    def eliminatable(self):
        return False

    def relocatable(self):
        return False

[...]
arg = claripy.BVS(..., annotations=(MyAnnotation(),))
[...]
```

**Extra details on environments**
Machine 1:
```
angr environment report
=============================
Date: 2019-04-02 18:18:55.521678
Running in virtual environment at [my venv dir]
Platform: macosx-10.14-x86_64
Python version: 3.6.1 (dab365a465140aa79a5f3ba4db784c4af4d5c195, Feb 18 2019, 10:53:27)
[PyPy 7.0.0-alpha0 with GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 10.0.0 (clang-1000.11.45.5)]
######## angr #########
Python found it in /Users/craig/angr/angr
Pip version not found!
Git info:
        Current commit 97fd492f8f94be7b12513d04c46cac16baccc9fb from branch master
        Checked out from remote origin: git@github.com:cdisselkoen/angr
######## ailment #########
Python found it in [my venv dir]/site-packages/ailment
Pip version ailment 8.19.2.4
######## cle #########
Python found it in /Users/craig/cle/cle
Pip version not found!
Git info:
        Current commit f5d43bdd279309c9833ce4c2fbadbb68843fd383 from branch master
        Checked out from remote origin: git@github.com:angr/cle
######## pyvex #########
Python found it in /Users/craig/pyvex/pyvex
Pip version pyvex 8.19.2.4
Git info:
        Current commit 6b9828885fd0ef8e309460d29d01b60220f96199 from branch master
        Checked out from remote origin: git@github.com:angr/pyvex
######## claripy #########
Python found it in /Users/craig/claripy/claripy
Pip version not found!
Git info:
        Current commit da3c05c7ad2dea231ce06a94748d79d4a9c04afe from branch master
```

title: Fix for incorrect block.size during CFG normalilzation for ARM arch
body: Block size will be calculated incorrectly if block "n" is in thumb mode and "smallest_node" is in arm mode. It will lack 1 byte.

title: Correct strchr behaviour when c==0x00
body:
From man 3 strchr:
> ... The terminating null byte is considered part of the string, so that if c is specified as '\0', these functions return a pointer to the terminator.


Could also optimize to always return s_addr+strlen when c == 0x00, but that would be a premature optimization from my part.

title: not every time an target pointer has a valid value
body:
1. `load_size` is incorrect in my case. It should be 8 but `load_size` gives me 4.
2. `_fast_memory_load_pointer` actually is a wrapper around memory load, so it is possible that the address is not mapped at all.

title: CFG.normalize(): Do not crash on completely overlapping nodes.
body:
Overlapping nodes might happen due to bugs or errors in CFG recovery. One
such example can be found in Nucleo_read_hyperterminal-stripped.elf (with
force_complete_scan=True), caused by incorrectly performing ARM block
creation from 0x8002bb4 (that is, if we do not force the entire binary to
be lifted as THUMB mode). This commit prevents normalize() from crashing
on such overlapping nodes.

title: Fix create in FunctionManager.function().
body: It was effectively disabled in a previous refactor.

title: VariableRecovery: Handle BVV register offsets. Closes #1430.
CFGFast: Make pending jobs LIFO

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

body:
Now we first pop the jobs that are added last. This way we prioritize popping jobs from "inner functions" -- functions that are scanned later during CFG recovery.

Without this fix, we incorrectly mark `__wrap_main()` (0x8000bd5) as returning in binary `Nucleo_read_hyperterminal-stripped.elf` on Python 3.6+ (because `dict`s are ordered starting from Python 3.6). This issue is exposed on Travis CI and cause the test case `test_tail_call_optimization_detection_armel()` to fail since our test VM image on Travis CI was still using Python 3.5.

title: Add repr_addr() to codenode.py.
body: The method was removed during the Java support merge.

title: Fix bug in pysoot delayed import in CFGFastSoot
body:
* CfgFstSoot was broken due to an incorrect delayed import of pysoot.

~* A critical deprecation warning was triggered because of an incorrect use of `state.se` instead of  `state.solver`.~

title: is_hooked inconsistency between codenode and project
body:
There are three(as far as I know) interfaces(CFGNode, CodeNode, angr.Project) where you can check whether an address is hooked.
And I found their results are different, sometimes confusing.
To reproduce:
~~~
import angr
proj = angr.Project('./CADET_00002')#angr-dev/binaries/tests/cgc
cfg = angr.analyses.CFGFast(normalize=True)
node = cfg.get_any_node(0xa000001)#should be the address of a syscall
print(node.is_syscall)# false # doesn't look right to me
print(node.is_simprocedure)# true # even more confusing
print(node.to_codenode().is_hook)# true # OK?
print(proj.is_hooked(node.addr))# false # ???
~~~

title: Confusing error with mismatched symbolic value sizes
body:
**Describe the bug**
This is less of a bug report and more of a report on a confusing error message. Essentially, if you have a size mismatch when storing a symbolic value in memory, the warnings that it raises is different depending on how you store it, and in one case it is quite misleading. After speaking to Fish about it, it seemed worthwhile to open an issue.

**Environment Information**
Environment information is a bit weird as this occurred on an internal branch of angr, but angr is version 8.8.10.5. I don't really think the environment is the issue here regardless.

**To Reproduce**
From any state with any binary:
```
fresh_symval = clarity.BVS('somename', 3)
state.memory.store(some_addr,fresh_symval)
```
This will raise 
```
angr.storage.paged_memory | Nothing left of the memory object to store in Simpage
```
The issue here is that a 3 bit symbolic value has no business being stored in byte addressable memory. The warning is a bit misleading here, as it makes it appear to be some sort of paging error, when the issue is actually a size mismatch.

if you instead try:
```
state.mem.int32_t[some_addr] = fresh_symval
```
You get the more useful error message of
```
ValueError: size of expression is wrong for type
```
Which is what helped me originally diagnose the problem.
I think more informative errors in the first case would be very helpful, and that pointing out size mismatch is probably the best way to do this.

Thank you for your time

title: ld-linux-x86_64.so.2 name issue
body:
*Disclaimer: The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers. While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best. For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*

---

**Describe the bug**
In lib.set_library_names() of /angr/procedures/definitions/linux_loader.py, the name of library 'ld-linux-x86_64.so.2' maybe use 'ld-linux-x86-64.so.2'.

The underline '_' between 86 and 64 maybe need change to '-'.
