title: fail to print debug representation of backward slice
body:
**Describe the bug**
When playing with `BackwardSlice`, it crashes.

**To Reproduce**
~~~
import angr
import logging
logging.getLogger('angr.analyses.backward_slice').setLevel('DEBUG')


b = angr.Project('/home/kylebot/src/angr-dev/angr-doc/examples/fauxware/fauxware', auto_load_libs=False)
cfg = b.analyses.CFGEmulated(keep_state=True,
                                 state_add_options=angr.sim_options.refs,
                                 context_sensitivity_level=2)
cdg = b.analyses.CDG(cfg)
ddg = b.analyses.DDG(cfg)
target_func = cfg.kb.functions.function(name="exit")
target_node = cfg.get_any_node(target_func.addr)

bs = b.analyses.BackwardSlice(cfg, cdg=cdg, ddg=ddg, targets=[ (target_node, -1) ])

print(bs.dbg_repr())
~~~

title: UserHook: Fix the issue of skipping adjacent hooks.
body:
If a hook follows a previous one immediately, it would be skipped, which
was an incorrect behavior. This commit fixes the issue and adds two test
cases to make sure hooks work as expected.

Thanks @graux-pierre for reporting this issue.

title: I got TypeError: copy() got an unexpected keyword argument 'stashes'
Clinic: General improvements.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Some subsystem of angr needs tweaking

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Adding a new control knob to something

body:
- Better strategies for linking variables to AIL expressions.
- Leverage StackPointerTracker analysis to track stack pointers and stack
  base pointers.
- Leverage reaching definitions in function simplification pass and
  call-site making pass for better results.
- Perform a full-function optimization pass at the end of the analysis.
- Fix a bug where _update_graph() does not clear the current graph before
  updating it.

title: Structurer: Specify addresses for loops.
body: Newly structured loops do not always have the original loop header as the first statement in its body. Hence we must manually specify addresses for loops.

title: Structurer: Fix loop exit recognition.
Definition: Fix two issues that may lead to crashes.
CFBlanket: Fix an off-by-one error in _mark_unknowns_core().
CFGBase: Skip all hooks and syscalls when merging nodes.
body: Closes #1333.

title: CFGBase: When merging two CFGNodes, query CFG instead of rebuilding blocks.
body:
This is because CFG recovery may have already split or altered existing
CFGNodes. Creating a block again does not account for those changes.

This commit closes issue #1329.

#!/usr/bin/env python
import os
import sys
import angr
import claripy

def analyze(binary_path):
    proj = angr.Project(binary_path, use_sim_procedures=True, default_analysis_mode='symbolic', auto_load_libs=False)

    # CFG construction: fast
    cfg = proj.analyses.CFGFast()

    # VFG construction
    vfg = proj.analyses.VFG(cfg=cfg)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    analyze(sys.argv[1])
```

title: Split UnresolvableTarget into UnresolvableJumptarget and UnresolvableCallTarget
Fix several bugs in Reassembler
body:
Make it work on Linux x64 binaries. Thanks Antonio F. Montoya from GrammaTech for reporting these issues.

The following PRs must be merged first:
- https://github.com/angr/pyvex/pull/176
- https://github.com/angr/cle/pull/165

title: CFGFast incurs AssertionError & ClaripyBackendError
body:
**Version**
https://github.com/angr/angr/commit/cf5374a554615242dd4fd92964c20920d7a9ffe4

**Test program**
```python
import os

import angr
from angr import SimProcedure
from angr.procedures import SIM_LIBRARIES, SIM_PROCEDURES

test_location = str(os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)))


# A wrong implementation of this function. But why CFGFast asks for successors of this SimProcedure?
class __underflow(SimProcedure):
    def run(self, file_ptr):
        ch = '\n'
        self.inline_call(SIM_PROCEDURES['libc']['fputc'], ch, file_ptr)
        return self.state.solver.Unconstrained('__underflow', 32, uninitialized=False)


def test():
    path = os.path.join(test_location, "libc-2.27.so")
    p = angr.Project(path, auto_load_libs=False)
    # p.hook_symbol('__underflow', __underflow()) // uncomment will cause ClaripyBackendError
    # it should not crash
    _ = p.analyses.CFGFast(show_progressbar=True)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    test()
```

Environment: All angr libraries are up-to-date. 
```
#!/usr/bin/env python
import os
import sys 
import time
import logging


import nose
import angr
import claripy



def analyze(binary_path):
    start = time.time()
    proj = angr.Project(binary_path, use_sim_procedures=True, default_analysis_mode='symbolic')
    entry_state = proj.factory.entry_state()
    setup_time = time.time()
    duration_setup = setup_time- start

    print('Finish initialization: %0.2fs' %(duration_setup))

    cfg = proj.analyses.CFGEmulated(keep_state=True, initial_state= entry_state, enable_advanced_backward_slicing=True, context_sensitivity_level=4)
    end = time.time()

    duration = end - start
    program_name = os.path.basename(binary_path)

    print ('Finished: \'%s\', run in time: %0.2fs, setup time: %0.2fs' %(program_name, duration, duration_setup))



if __name__ == '__main__':

    if len(sys.argv) < 2:  
        print ('Please give a binary path')
        exit(0)

    if  not os.path.isfile(sys.argv[1]):
        print ('File does not exist!')
        exit(0)

    analyze(sys.argv[1])
```

Attached please kindly find the binary. Thanks.

title: cfg copy fails
body:
I have a `CFGFast` instance. I want to make a copy of it and do some modification to it.
However,  the copy seems to be missing a lot of attributes.

To reproduce,
~~~
import angr
proj = angr.Project('/bin/ls', auto_load_libs=False) 
cfg = proj.analyses.CFGFast(normalize=True)
cfg_copy = cfg.copy()

assert cfg.project is not None
assert cfg_copy.project is not None# it should fail

assert cfg._name is not None
assert cfg_copy._name is not None# it should fail
~~~

Of course I can add these two to `CFGFast`, but I hope that someone could have a thorough look at it.

title: CFGFast: Avoid generating blocks that go across function boundaries.
body:
Now blocks will always be cut at function boundaries. Both blocks and
function boundaries will be refined during Stage 2 in
_process_irrational_function_starts(). This commit fixes issue #1312.

title: CFG Party Foul: Function prologue false-positive causes function fragmentation
body:
*Disclaimer: The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers. While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best. For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*

---

**Describe the bug**
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.

In `mbed_copy_nvic` (ox08000b99) of `tests/armel/Nucleo_read_hyperterminal-stripped.elf`
we mis-identify the function prologue (WTF is GCC even doing???) and lose an instruction at the beginning of the function.  The function is called directly, by `software_init_hook`, which is called eventually from the entry point.

My suspicion about what's going on here is yet another ordering thing regarding function recovery.  software_init_hook is discovered via indirect jump resolution, as its address is loaded out of what would be a relocation.  This is one of those things our fixed-up IJ resolver handles.  However, by the time IJs get resolved, we have already found the wrong function start point, and things get messy.

Obviously this is specific to the forthcoming features of fix/arm_cfg_party_2, as we have thumb prologues turned on.

**Environment Information**
Many common issues are caused by problems with the local Python environment.
Before submitting, double-check that your versions of all modules in the angr suite (angr, cle, pyvex, ...) are up to date.
Please include the output of `python -m angr.misc.bug_report` here.
`fix/arm_cfg_party_2`

**To Reproduce**
Please include *both a script to reproduce the crash, and attach the binary used, if possible*
```
p = angr.Project("Nucleo_read_hyperterminal-stripped.elf")                                                       
cfg = p.analyses.CFGFast(normalize=True, collect_data_references=True, force_complete_scan=False, resolve_indirect_jumps=True, detect_tail_calls=True) 
f = p.kb.functions[0x08000b99]
for bl in f.blocks():
    bl.pp()
```

Should be more than just the ldr instruction
Check out the non-stripped version of the binary in the repo to see what i mean

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

title: Fix SimSymbolicMemory._find() in tracing mode.
body:
_find() wasn't adding constraints for preconstrained input bytes if
those bytes are not equal to the byte we are looking for. However,
preconstraints will get removed after tracing is over. As a result, we
might generate input data that do not satisfy _find() anymore.

title: Set state again for SimFiles in socketqueue before using.
body:
We do not copy socketqueue when SimFileSystem branches. As a result, the
state that socketqueue elements are referencing might have long gone
when we use them (.state is a weakref).

title: Fix mountpoint resolution by matching deeper paths first.
body: Otherwise `/xxx` would never get matched if `/` exists as a mountpoint.

title: Fix a bug in CFG/Function normalization.
body:
I was assuming that a block can be split into at most two different
blocks, and the first half only has a boring jump targeting the second
half. Unfortunately, this is not the case in ARM. This bug is triggered
when normalizing CFG for ARM binary "a_thingy-stripped.elf" (see angr
issue #1286), function 0x8002b71. The block 0x8002b70 can be split into
four small blocks.

title: Cachetools broke their API
body:
There's a new major version of cachetools (providing LRUCache), 3.0.0. This has caused everything to break. I have pinned our version to `cachetools<3` for the time being, but we should migrate.

My guess is that this is because we were using the `missing` argument to LRUCache (in claripy, specifically), and I am fairly sure the intended replacement is to [implement the `__missing__` method](https://cachetools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#extending-cache-classes). Unsure if there are more implications, which is why this issue is open under angr instead of claripy.

title: Fix Keystone for ARM THUMB mode. Add a test case for it.
Call set_state() on socket pairs.
CFGFast: Double-check to_outside when applying transition edges. Closes #1266.
body: Thanks @subwire for reporting this issue.

title: VariableRecovery: Only insert states with concrete IPs. Closes #1264.
body: Thanks @mephi42 for reporting this issue.

title: CFG party foul: improper propagation of returning status
body:

**Describe the bug**
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
(binary attached)
mbed::mbed_fdopen (0x08005275) gets chopped off by its call to memcpy(0x08004de1).  memcpy gets figured out correctly, the caller is marked as nonreturning, and truncates at the call (same goes for a bunch of other stuff calling memcpy, from what i can tell)

title: ARM64 ccall value truncating
body:
Hello, I am trying to symbolically run the following state:

```
>>> state
<SimState @ 0x87d6c8>
>>> state.solver.constraints
[]
>>> proj.factory.block(0x87d6c8).pp()

>>> state.regs.w2
<BV32 reg_x2_13_32{UNINITIALIZED}>
>>> state.regs.x1
<BV64 reg_x1_14_64{UNINITIALIZED}>
>>> proj.factory.block(0x87d6c8).vex.pp()
IRSB {
  t0:Ity_I64 t1:Ity_I64 t2:Ity_I32 t3:Ity_I32 t4:Ity_I32 t5:Ity_I64 t6:Ity_I64 t7:Ity_I64 t8:Ity_I64 t9:Ity_I64 t10:Ity_I64 t11:Ity_I32 t12:Ity_I32 t13:Ity_I64 t14:Ity_I64 t15:Ity_I64 t16:Ity_I1 t17:Ity_I64 t18:Ity_I64 t19:Ity_I64 t20:Ity_I64 t21:Ity_I64 t22:Ity_I64 t23:Ity_I64

  00 | ------ IMark(0x87d6c8, 4, 0) ------
  01 | t9 = GET:I64(r1)
  02 | t8 = Add64(t9,0x000000000000000c)
  03 | t11 = LDle:I32(t8)
  04 | t10 = 32Uto64(t11)
  05 | PUT(r2) = t10
  06 | ------ IMark(0x87d6cc, 4, 0) ------
  07 | t12 = 64to32(t10)
  08 | t14 = 32Uto64(t12)
  09 | PUT(cc_op) = 0x0000000000000001
  10 | PUT(cc_dep1) = t14
  11 | PUT(cc_dep2) = 0x0000000000000001
  12 | PUT(cc_ndep) = 0x0000000000000000
  13 | PUT(pc) = 0x000000000087d6d0
  14 | ------ IMark(0x87d6d0, 4, 0) ------
  15 | t22 = arm64g_calculate_condition(0x0000000000000001,t14,0x0000000000000001,0x0000000000000000):Ity_I64
  16 | t16 = 64to1(t22)
  17 | if (t16) { PUT(pc) = 0x87d6f0; Ijk_Boring }
  NEXT: PUT(pc) = 0x000000000087d6d4; Ijk_Boring
}
```

However, when I step the branch is never taken:

```
>>> next = state.step()
>>> next.successors
[<SimState @ 0x87d6d4>]
>>> next.unsat_successors
[<SimState @ 0x87d6f0>]
>>> next.unsat_successors[0].solver.unsat_core()
[<Bool ((0#32 .. mem_fffffffff000000c_12_32) + 0x1) == 0x0>]
>>> next.unsat_successors[0].solver.constraints
[<Bool True>, <Bool (reg_x1_11_64 + 0xc) <= 0xffffffffffffffff>, <Bool (reg_x1_11_64 + 0xc) == 0xfffffffff000000c>, <Bool ((0#32 .. mem_fffffffff000000c_12_32) + 0x1) == 0x0>]
```

After having posted the question on slack, someone found a problem in the implementation of the ccall `ARM64G_CC_OP_ADD32` (`angr/engines/vex/ccall.py`).

The problem comes from truncating values stuff.

title: fix color of log messages
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Now `angr` has been ported to python3, and built in function `hash()` behaves differently from that in python2. Now, hash value stays the same in a certain session, but varies from session to session.
Note that `angr` use this code to generate colors of log message:
~~~
color = hash(record.name) % 7 + 31
record.name = ("\x1b[%dm" % color) + record.name + "\x1b[0m"
~~~
Which means log message will vary from session to session. This is not user friendly.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Solution:
use other hash functions, like md5, sha1 etc. (I tried some, sha512 looks good, at least the most common messages are not white.)

title: CFGFast: Fix a bug that may cause missing jumpout sites.
body:
In some cases, CFGFast might fail to set the jumpout sites of a function
if:
- The function does not have any return instructions, and
- The function has a tail jump that jumps to another function that
  returns.

This is because in the second phase of CFG recovery, we are directly
copying the returning setting of all functions that has been previously
found (during the first phase). If a function has been incorrectly marked
as not returning during the first phase, we will then inherit the false
positive in the second phase.

The obvious solution is to only inherit true positives (functions that
must return) from the first analysis phase.

title: Type error in in string_references()
body:
*Disclaimer: The angr suite is maintained by a small team of volunteers. While we cannot guarantee any timeliness for fixes and enhancements, we will do our best. For more real-time help with angr, from us and the community, join our [Slack.](http://angr.io/invite/)*

---

**Describe the bug**
Please include a clear and concise description of what the bug is.
There is a type error occurred in string_references() function
Here is the log
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".\src\gaeInputGeneration.py", line 109, in <module>
    for offset, strRef in func.string_references(vex_only=True):
  File "C:\Users\lixue\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\site-packages\angr\knowledge_plugins\functions\function.py", line 301, in string_references
    while current_char in string.printable:
TypeError: 'in <string>' requires string as left operand, not int
```
And here is a snapshot of your code in function.py
```python
for addr in self.local_runtime_values if not vex_only else self.code_constants:
    if not isinstance(addr, claripy.fp.FPV) and addr in memory:
        # check that the address isn't an pointing to known executable code
        # and that it isn't an indirect pointer to known executable code
        try:
            possible_pointer = memory.unpack_word(addr)
            if addr not in known_executable_addresses and possible_pointer not in known_executable_addresses:
                # build string
                stn = ""
                offset = 0
                current_char = memory[addr + offset]
                while current_char in string.printable:
                    stn += current_char
                    offset += 1
                    current_char = memory[addr + offset]

                # check that the string was a null terminated string with minimum length
                if current_char == "\x00" and len(stn) >= minimum_length:
                    strings.append((addr, stn))
        except KeyError:
            pass
return strings
```
In this piece of code, the ``current_char`` from ``memory[addr + offset]`` is a integer instead of <string>.
However, it cannot be transformed to string by `` current_char = str(memory[addr + offset])`` directly. (It might be unicode or sthing? idk)
This code works well under python2

title: Identifier needs further updating for filesystem refactor
body:
in angr/angr/state_plugins, line 476
~~~
stdin = state.posix.stdin.load(0, pos)
~~~
in angr/angr/analyses/identifier/runner.py, line 300
~~~
stdout = result_state.posix.stdout.load(0, result_state.posix.stdout.size)
~~~
stdin and stdout have been transformed to be `SimPacketsStream`, which makes above lines invalid. They don't have a `load` function like memory.

But I don't know fix how to fix it elegantly.

BTW, I wonder how to add constraints directly on stdin. I used to write something like `state.se.add(state.posix.files[0] == someting)`. But `state.posix.files[0]` does not work any more.

title: Failed jumptable resolution leads to CFG exception
body:
I'm trying to run CFGFast on a relatively small Thumbv2 binary. During the resolution of a particular jump table, claripy is unable to solve for a particular minimum:

```
angr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/claripy/frontends/light_frontend.pyc in min(self, e, extra_constraints, exact)
     58             return self._solver_backend.min(e)
     59         except BackendError:
---> 60             raise ClaripyFrontendError("Light solver can't handle this min().")
     61 
     62     def solution(self, e, v, extra_constraints=(), exact=None):

SimSolverModeError: ('Translated claripy error:', <class 'claripy.errors.ClaripyFrontendError'>, ClaripyFrontendError("Light solver can't handle this min().",))
```
This stems from CFG's jumptable resolver:
```
angr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/angr/analyses/cfg/indirect_jump_resolvers/jumptable.pyc in resolve(self, cfg, addr, func_addr, block, jumpkind)
    192                 jump_table = [ ]
    193 
--> 194                 min_jump_target = state.se.min(jump_addr)
    195                 max_jump_target = state.se.max(jump_addr)
    196 
```
I understand that sometimes these constraints cannot be solved, but this seems like the kind of error that could be handled and discarded in CFGFast in order to yield a best-attempt CFG.

The binary is attached (note that the majority of the 4.4M is dwarf data).
[mpex.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/2215466/mpex.zip)

what's wrong with the following code?
```python
base = 0x60008000
proj = angr.Project(target, auto_load_libs = False, load_options = {'main_opts':{'custom_base_addr': base}})
```
error message.
```bash
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/networkx-2.1-py2.7.egg/networkx/classes/digraph.py", line 523, in remove_node
    raise NetworkXError("The node %s is not in the digraph." % (n,))
networkx.exception.NetworkXError: The node <CFGNode 0x806ea140[20]> is not in the digraph.
```
I think it is caused by a bug in the base address.

title: Thumb tail call issue in CFGFast
body:
In Thumb binaries, functions that contain a tail call will sometimes be marked by CFGFast as not returning. For example, the following code results in the `add_5` function being marked as not returning (`returning == False`):

```
        .section .text
        .code 16
        .global add
add:
        ADD r0, r0, r1
        MOV pc, lr

        .global add_5
add_5:
        MOVS r1, #5
        B add

        .global main
main:
        PUSH {lr}
        MOVS r0, #2
        MOVS r1, #3
        BL add
        BL add_5
        POP {PC}
```
An assembled version of the above is attached along with a script exhibiting the behavior.

[thumb-tailcall.zip](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/2199855/thumb-tailcall.zip)

title: Difference between Dominator and Dominating Set
body: Code in https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/master/angr/analyses/veritesting.py#L578 may confuse the concepts of dominator and dominating set. To my best knowledge, the function which is needed here is `networkx.immediate_dominators()`

title: Crash on read file after opening symbolic file
body:
Hello,
I've encounter a crash in some weird scenario,
I've run 2 tests, first one crashes the second one doesn't (file_path is symbolic):
```
#include <stdio.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <fcntl.h>

void crash_read(char* file_path) {
        int filedesc = 0;
        unsigned char buf = 0;
        char s[250] = {0};

        snprintf(s, 0x40u, "%s/value", file_path);
        filedesc = open(s, 0);
        read(filedesc, &buf, 1u);
}
```

This one does not crashes:
```
#include <unistd.h>
#include <fcntl.h>

void not_crash_read(char* file_path) {
        int filedesc = 0;
        unsigned char buf = 0;
        filedesc = open(file_path, 0);
        read(filedesc, &buf, 1u);
}

title: Adding an init $t9 for ReachingDefinitionAnalysis with MIPS.
body: If $t9 isn't initialized to the address of the function in mips all the function calls will result in an undefined IP error in the engines. After this change the user is prompted to define their own function handlers (as expected)

title: Identifier unreferenced variable
body:
Test file `test.py`:
```python
from patcherex.patch_master import PatchMaster
pm = PatchMaster(sys.argv[1])
patched_bin, ids_rule = pm.create_one_patch('medium_reassembler_optimized')
```
Run:
`python test.py ../patcherex/test_binaries/CADET_00003`

In `angr/angr/analyses/identifier/identify.py`, line 591:
```python
                        if stmt.offset == self.project.arch.sp_offset:
                            found_end = True
                            ends.add(a.ins_addr)
                            all_end_addrs.add(cur_addr)
```
Variable `a` is not referenced.

title: VFG is generated without any edges
body:
@jackaaron and I figured out was that `VFGJob` was being created without a source block ID.  The source block ID seems to be used to generate the edges between a node and its predecessor by `vfg._graph_add_edge`.  If a VFGJob is created without a `src_block_id`, then no edges are created.

With the below changes, we were able to get a reasonable VFG with edges.

```diff
diff --git angr/analyses/vfg.py angr/analyses/vfg.py
index 9af3bcc..508e845 100644
--- angr/analyses/vfg.py
+++ angr/analyses/vfg.py
@@ -404,7 +404,8 @@ class VFG(ForwardAnalysis, Analysis):   # pylint:disable=abstract-method
                 return n
 
     def irsb_from_node(self, node):
-        return self.project.factory.successors(node.state, addr=node.addr, num_inst=len(node.instruction_addrs))
+         num_inst = len(self.project.factory.block(addr=node.addr).instruction_addrs)
+         return self.project.factory.successors(node.state, addr=node.addr, num_inst=num_inst)
 
     def get_paths(self, begin, end):
         """
@@ -415,6 +416,7 @@ class VFG(ForwardAnalysis, Analysis):   # pylint:disable=abstract-method
         a_paths = []
         for p in paths:
             runs = map(self.irsb_from_node, p)
+            raise DeprecationWarning("angr.path.make_path() is no longer")
             a_paths.append(angr.path.make_path(self.project, runs))
         return a_paths
 
@@ -989,7 +991,8 @@ class VFG(ForwardAnalysis, Analysis):   # pylint:disable=abstract-method
         merged_state, _ = self._merge_states(state_0, state_1)
 
         new_job = VFGJob(jobs[0].addr, merged_state, self._context_sensitivity_level, jumpkind=jobs[0].jumpkind,
-                         block_id=jobs[0].block_id, call_stack=jobs[0].call_stack
+                         block_id=jobs[0].block_id, call_stack=jobs[0].call_stack,
+                         src_block_id=[jobs[0].src_block_id, jobs[1].src_block_id] # XXX: something bad might happen
                          )
 
         self._top_function_analysis_task.jobs.append(new_job)
@@ -1040,7 +1043,8 @@ class VFG(ForwardAnalysis, Analysis):   # pylint:disable=abstract-method
         # import ipdb; ipdb.set_trace()
 
         new_job = VFGJob(jobs[0].addr, new_state, self._context_sensitivity_level, jumpkind=jobs[0].jumpkind,
-                         block_id=jobs[0].block_id, call_stack=jobs[0].call_stack
+                         block_id=jobs[0].block_id, call_stack=jobs[0].call_stack,
+                         src_block_id=[jobs[0].src_block_id, jobs[1].src_block_id] # XXX: something bad might happen
                          )
         self._top_function_analysis_task.jobs.append(new_job)
 
@@ -1316,8 +1320,10 @@ class VFG(ForwardAnalysis, Analysis):   # pylint:disable=abstract-method
             self.graph.add_node(dst_node)
 
         else:
-            src_node = self._graph_get_node(src_block_id, terminator_for_nonexistent_node=True)
-            self.graph.add_edge(src_node, dst_node, **kwargs)
+            src_block_id = [src_block_id] if not isinstance(src_block_id,list) else src_block_id
+            for src_blk_id in src_block_id:
+                src_node = self._graph_get_node(src_blk_id, terminator_for_nonexistent_node=True)
+                self.graph.add_edge(src_node, dst_node, **kwargs)
 
     #
     # Other methods
@@ -1428,6 +1434,7 @@ class VFG(ForwardAnalysis, Analysis):   # pylint:disable=abstract-method
                                  block_id=new_block_id,
                                  jumpkind='Ijk_Ret',
                                  call_stack=new_call_stack,
+                                 src_block_id=job._block_id
                                  )
 
                 new_jobs.append(new_job)
@@ -1473,6 +1480,7 @@ class VFG(ForwardAnalysis, Analysis):   # pylint:disable=abstract-method
                              block_id=new_block_id,
                              jumpkind=successor_state.history.jumpkind,
                              call_stack=new_call_stack,
+                             src_block_id=job._block_id
                              )
 
             if successor.history.jumpkind == 'Ijk_Ret':
@@ -1711,6 +1719,7 @@ class VFG(ForwardAnalysis, Analysis):   # pylint:disable=abstract-method
                      block_id=block_id,
                      jumpkind=state.history.jumpkind,
                      call_stack=call_stack,
+                     src_block_id=job_key._block_id
                      )
         self._insert_job(job)
```

We thought that by getting a graph with nodes containing successors that we would be able to get a VSA DDG with nodes, but alas that was not to be.  We ran into a situation similar to what was asked in https://lists.cs.ucsb.edu/pipermail/angr/2018-January/000427.html.  Either our mods weren't right or there might be some other issues.

title: Lifter: Fix the crash caused by lifting a block with unfilled holes in memory under fastpath mode. Closes #1062.
body:
When a state under fastpath mode is given, it will throw a
SimSolverModeError upon calling eval() on the block bytes if the block is
not continuous, i.e., there are holes of missing memory bytes that must be
filled with unconstrained symbolic variables. This commit address this
issue by catching SimErrors and falling back to the slow path after the
exception occurs.

Hello,

I'm trying to use the unique explore technique very simply like so:
```
    technique = angr.exploration_techniques.UniqueSearch()
    simgr.use_technique(technique)
    simgr.run()

Whenever I try to run with the technique I receive the following exception:

On the following line:

unique_state = min(self.uniqueness.items(), key=lambda e: e[1])[0]

```

title: "loader.provide_symbol" has been removed
body:
Hi, angr is amazing. I start to learn from its code and then find an abandoned function still used in `hook_symbol`:
```py
        if type(obj) in (int, long):
            # this is pretty intensely sketchy
            l.info("Instructing the loader to re-point symbol %s at address %#x", symbol_name, obj)
            self.loader.provide_symbol(self.loader.extern_object, symbol_name, AT.from_mva(obj, self.loader.extern_object).to_rva())
            return obj
```
`loader.provide_symbol` has been removed since this commit 186096775932d8fa844d9532a1f180bc2553f7d7

title: Question: ARM32 Framepointer/Basepointer/Stackpointer
body:
Forgive me my writing, kinda was in a hurry. So now more clear - as I'am now quite sure that the fix is already quite simple, I think - but not that sure. 

Hello, have another post - this time regarding something i noticed today in ARM32. So this is basically a question at first

The registers in ARM32 say that:
```python
'bp': (60, 4),
'r13': (60, 4),
'sp': (60, 4),
```

So this always leads to the fact that `sp` is equal to `bp`, reagardless of `stack_push` operations. Actually, this is not a big deal because `arm32` does not have a `bp` anyway. I just stumpled upon this in `dbg_print_stack` where the stack size is calculated by `bp - sp` and this leads always to a `depth of 0` in `arm32`. 

However, `arm32` has something quite similar to a `bp` - the framepointer `fp`, which usually is `r7 (thumb), r11 (thumb-2/arm)`. So as far as I understand, the `bp_offset` should be either equal to `r7 (thumb)`or `r11 (thumb-2, arm)`. The same goes for `bp`. 

So, the main question is - how do I tell archinfo the `bp_offset` and `bp` offset is, well - dependent on thumb or not. Like `bp_offset = 52(r11 - fp arm) if not thumb else 36 (r7 - fp thumb)`

Could be that I'm quite wrong here - before making a pull request, I'd rather have a second opinion

body:
I am using CFGAccurate to analysis a binary. Below is apart of the binary code
```
.text:0000B5D4 loc_B5D4                                ; CODE XREF: sub_B264:loc_B5D0↑j
.text:0000B5D4                 LDR     R0, [R11,#var_A4]
.text:0000B5D8                 STR     R0, [R11,#var_C4]
.text:0000B5DC                 LDR     R0, [R11,#var_C4] ; s
.text:0000B5E0                 BL      strlen
.text:0000B5E4                 ADD     R0, R0, #1
.text:0000B5E8                 STR     R0, [R11,#var_C8]
.text:0000B5EC                 LDR     R0, [R11,#var_C8]
.text:0000B5F0                 ADD     R0, R0, #7
.text:0000B5F4                 BIC     R0, R0, #7
.text:0000B5F8                 SUB     R0, SP, R0
.text:0000B5FC                 MOV     SP, R0
```

Angr could locate the node 0xb5d4. However, it thinks the node at 0xb5e4 is the PathTerminator.
```
In [8]: cfg.get_any_node(0xb5d4)
Out[8]: <CFGNode 0xb5d4[16]>
```

```
In [9]: cfg.get_any_node(0xb5e4)
Out[9]: <CFGNode PathTerminator 0xb5e4>
```

I don't think this is a right behavior. Can anyone give some suggestions or need further information. Many Thanks

title: Callgraph: Add orphan functions to the call graph.

title: Fixed when `bound_reached` callback is triggered
body: `bound_reached` callback was being called before the specified bound argument is reached. My changes fixes that issues and calls **provided** `bound_reached` callback only when **provided** `bound` argument is reached by the loop.

title: Catch SimSolverError in CFGAccurate
body:
A `SimSolverError` exception may be raised when evaluating a `BVS` instance that represented a memory address used in a read. This occurs when the `BackendConcrete` backend fails handling a `BVS`.

Apologies for all these merge commits, let me know if you want a rebased commit.

Fix several cases of undefined names. Closes #1002.

title: Incorrect stack alignment on x86-64
body:
I'm trying to get my rust binary running under `angr` for symbolic execution.  I've pared it down to, well, nothing:
```
#![feature(alloc_system, global_allocator, allocator_api)]

extern crate alloc_system;

use alloc_system::System;

#[global_allocator]
static A: System = System;

fn main() {
    return;
}
```
(We use the system allocator here instead of `jemalloc`, Rust's default, to avoid having to patch out a bunch of syscalls.)

You can build this binary by starting a new crate with `cargo init --bin` and using that as the `src/main.rs` file.  LMK if you'd like more detail for building the rust side, of course.  (Or I can send you a binary.)

Then, I'm running this script inside the `angr/angr` docker container:
```
import angr

def main(p):
    proj = angr.Project(
        p,
        use_sim_procedures=True,
        translation_cache=True,
        support_selfmodifying_code=False,
    )

    # No-op the signal handler installation (for now)
    class signal(angr.SimProcedure):
        def run(self, *args, **kwargs):
            return 0

    proj.hook_symbol('signal', signal())

    opts = {
        angr.options.ZERO_FILL_UNCONSTRAINED_MEMORY,
        angr.options.STRICT_PAGE_ACCESS,
        angr.options.UNICORN,
    }
    entry_state = proj.factory.entry_state(
        add_options=opts,
        args={},
        env={},
    )

    simulation_manager = angr.SimulationManager(
        project=proj,
        active_states=[entry_state],
    )

    i = 0
    while len(simulation_manager.active) == 1 and not simulation_manager.errored:
        simulation_manager.step()
        i += 1

    if simulation_manager.active:
        print("Stopped with %d states!" % len(simulation_manager.active))
        actions = list(simulation_manager.active[0].history.actions)
        print actions[-1]

    elif simulation_manager.errored:
        errored = simulation_manager.errored[0]
        print("Errored: %s" % (errored.error,))
        state = errored.state
        print("rip: %s" % (state.regs.rip))
        print("rsp: %s" % (state.regs.rsp))
        print("rbp: %s" % (state.regs.rbp))
        proj.factory.block(state.solver.eval(state.regs.rip)).pp()
        print("")

        for frame in state.callstack:
            try:
                name = proj.kb.labels.get(frame.current_function_address)
            except KeyError:
                name = None
            print(">> %s" % (name,))
        print("")
        import ipdb; ipdb.set_trace()
```
The program steps through until...
```
Errored: Cannot execute following jumpkind Ijk_SigSEGV
rip: <BV64 0x407f54>
rsp: <BV64 0x7fffffffffefdb8>
rbp: <BV64 0x7fffffffffefe98>
0x407f54:	movaps	xmmword ptr [rbp - 0xc0], xmm0
0x407f5b:	movaps	xmmword ptr [rbp - 0xd0], xmm0
0x407f62:	movaps	xmmword ptr [rbp - 0xe0], xmm0
0x407f69:	mov	qword ptr [rbp - 0xb0], 0
0x407f74:	lea	rdi, [rbp - 0xe0]
0x407f7b:	call	0x4032c0

>> _ZN3std3sys4unix6thread5guard4init17ha4e308f7b00e4ed6E
>> _ZN3std2rt19lang_start_internal17hd640de3aab7bd269E
>> main
>> __libc_start_main
>> None
```
Note that `rbp` is not 16 byte aligned, so the `movaps` is going to fail with a protection fault.

If I run the same program directly, it works, and if I break at the offending instruction in `gdb`, `rbp` is indeed 16 byte aligned.

## Configuration
```
$ uname -a
Linux sujayakar-vm 4.4.0-119-generic #143-Ubuntu SMP Mon Apr 2 16:08:24 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
$ rustc --version
rustc 1.27.0-nightly (79252ff4e 2018-04-29)
```

title: Fix TreeIter.__len__().
Fix SimState.jumpkind.
body:
SimState.scratch.jumpkind is always None after copying a state, so we
cannot use SimState.jumpkind to retrieve the previous jumpkind in
history. Now it is correctly implemented by accessing state history.

title: Set function name to the name passed as parameter
body:
If you passed proj.kb.functions.function both a name and an address to create a new function like:
`proj.kb.functions.function(name='main', addr=0x1337, create=True)`
The resulting function would not have that name set.

title: Typo fix in sim_options.py.
Typo fix in sim_manager.py: resilence -> resilience.
angr.sim_type.parse_type Error
body:
Upon reaching a `sprintf(buf,"%lx",int)`, angr errors in the following block:
```python
try:
    typeobj = sim_type.parse_type(nugtype).with_arch(self.state.arch)
except Exception as e: #I added Exception for trace clarity
    raise SimProcedureError("%s\nformat specifier uses unknown type '%s'" % (str(e),repr(nugtype)))
```
From https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/master/angr/procedures/stubs/format_parser.py#L337
Results in:
```
<State errored with "'tuple' object has no attribute 'strip'
format specifier uses unknown type '('unsigned', 'long')'">
```
When you pass multiple format params for a single object the following line has a logic bug due to `defn` being a `tuple` instead of a `str`:
```python
defn = 'typedef ' + defn.strip('; \n\t\r') + ' QQQQ;'
```
From https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/master/angr/sim_type.py#L909

I tried patching with:
```python
if type(defn) is tuple:
    defn = ' '.join(defn)
```
But I just get a new error:
```
<State errored with "No module named ply.lex
format specifier uses unknown type '('unsigned', 'long')'">
```
And yes, `ply` is installed:
```
% ~/.local/bin/pip install ply --user
Requirement already satisfied: ply in /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages
```

I can get it to not error by changing https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/master/angr/sim_type.py#L848
and #L849:
```python
import ply.lex as lex
import ply.cpp as cpp
```
But I have no idea what's intended.

title: Calculating ccalls should only raise SimErrors, not other exceptions.
body: CFG recovery is impacted by this bug. Thanks @wubingwang for reporting.

title: Do not fail state stepping if we cannot solve the return address.
body:
This might happen when the return address is a symbolic value and we are
in fastpath mode (CFGAccurate). The hack is to use the address of
`UnresolvableTarget`.

This PR relies on PR #943.

title: SimSolver: Do not return a symbolic solver if SYMBOLIC is absent from state options.
body: This allows `fastpath` mode to work as expected: No Z3 solving should ever be done in `fastpath` mode.

title: setup.py: fix version for capstone
body: There should be never more than two dots: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/capstone/3.0.5rc2

title: Function: Determine whether it is a syscall or not if 'syscall' is not provided.
CFGFast: Call _add_returning_function() when needed.
CFGFast: Fix a wrong assignment in _analyze_all_function_features()
body: `new_returning_functions` and `new_not_returning_functions` were swapped.

title: _analyse_function_features(): Skip empty functions.
body: We used to always mark empty functions as returning - I wonder why no one notices anything wrong...

title: ForwardAnalysis: Store job_info to self._job_map regardless.
Tracer otiegnqwvk must be added after crashmonitor
body: If you do it the other way around it just doesn't work. Why? The crash manager is actually a pretty lightweight set of functionality that a) checks to see if the current IP is on the stack each frame and b) does the crash windup stuff. Someone should investigate this. Might be the complete functions running out of order?

Also removed excessive "continue" in the end of "for" operator.

title: added the option to track memory actions in cfg accurate
body:
If the flag enable_function_hints is set but the option TRACK_MEMORY_ACTIONS is not, CFGAccurate won't check any load/store to find function hints.
I added this option by default when enable_function_hints is set.

title: Fix/cfg accurate crashes
body:
Fixed two bugs:
* When building the CFGAccurate using the function hints flag, it might happen that a block has no successors. I added a check to prevent the analysis to break.

* simos.syscall might return None, in which case self.project.simos.syscall(new_state).addr would fail. I added a check right before that statement. I am not 100% of the implications this has on the CFG, but I believe it is correct.

title: CFGFast distance calculation problem for ARM
body:
Hi Guys!

I have spotted that there is some problem with "distance" calculation in CFGFast._generate_cfgnode() method for ARM binaries. In the code here:

https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/4238162b6ebc76598275e0b4bd7347838af3cd79/angr/analyses/cfg/cfg_fast.py#L3306-L3333

Consider following disassembly:

```
.text:00016EE4             loc_16EE4                               ; CODE XREF: __udivmoddi4:loc_16E7Cj
.text:00016EE4 2E 46                       MOV             R6, R5
.text:00016EE6 A8 E6                       B               loc_16C3A
.text:00016EE6             ; End of function __udivmoddi4
.text:00016EE6
.text:00016EE6             ; .text         ends
.text:00016EE6
.fini:00016EE8             ; ===========================================================================
.fini:00016EE8
.fini:00016EE8             ; Segment type: Pure code
.fini:00016EE8                             AREA .fini, CODE
```

Distance for the block 0x16ee5 will be caluclated as 3, as it is in thumb mode and thus is addr+1. So this block will miss 1 instruction. And the successor block, with addr 0x16EE7, won't be processed at all, cause its size will be 1.

May be it will be right to substitute "addr" with "addr&(~1)" for ARM arch in the distance calculation snippet?

title: JumpTableResolver: Performs a stricter check on jump targets.
body:
This will reduce the number of incorrectly resolved jump tables,
especially in binaries with weird behaviors (e.g., jumping to stack/heap).
An example is the binary example provided here:
https://github.com/angr/identifier/issues/1 .

title: Function.returning return False
body:
Hi, @ltfish 
Both the source code and the asm show that this function has return value.
```
const char* getCharFromString(JNIEnv* env, jstring string){
    if(string == NULL)
        return NULL;

    return  env->GetStringUTFChars(string ,0);
}
```
```
.text:00000578 ; =============== S U B R O U T I N E =======================================
.text:00000578
.text:00000578 ; Attributes: bp-based frame
.text:00000578
.text:00000578 ; getCharFromString(_JNIEnv *, _jstring *)
.text:00000578                 EXPORT _Z17getCharFromStringP7_JNIEnvP8_jstring
.text:00000578 _Z17getCharFromStringP7_JNIEnvP8_jstring
.text:00000578                                         ; DATA XREF: LOAD:00000188↑o
.text:00000578 ; __unwind {
.text:00000578                 PUSH    {R7,LR}
.text:0000057A                 ADD     R7, SP, #0
.text:0000057C                 MOVS    R2, #0
.text:0000057E                 CMP     R1, #0
.text:00000580                 BEQ     loc_590
.text:00000582                 MOVS    R2, #0x2A4
.text:00000586                 LDR     R3, [R0]
.text:00000588                 LDR     R3, [R3,R2]
.text:0000058A                 MOVS    R2, #0
.text:0000058C                 BLX     R3
.text:0000058E                 MOVS    R2, R0
.text:00000590
.text:00000590 loc_590                                 ; CODE XREF: getCharFromString(_JNIEnv *,_jstring *)+8↑j
.text:00000590                 MOVS    R0, R2
.text:00000592                 POP     {R7,PC}
.text:00000592 ; } // starts at 578
.text:00000592 ; End of function getCharFromString(_JNIEnv *,_jstring *)
```
And I get the jump kind of the last block, it return `Ijk_Ret`, but when I do `CFGAccurate` and then get the `Function.returning` of the function, it returns `False.`

title: fgets newline edgecase
Fix: decode_instruction() fails if capstone misses mips.MIPS_GRP_*.
body:
This commit fixes the issue that angr Management crashes when
disassembling functions if the installed capstone is too old.

title: Disassembly: Fix for NetworkX 2.
Incorrect modeling of strncpy
body:
In the man page of strncpy(), it says

If the length of src is less than n, strncpy() writes additional null bytes to dest to ensure that a total of n bytes are written.

But current strncpy() does put addional null bytes to the destination, which makes the different behavior with normal strncpy().

title: Disassembly cannot render ARM instruction
body:
Hi,

`Disassembly` does not display correctly this kind of instruction `str r2, [r3, #4]`. In fact, the instruction has 3 operands, but `capstone` instruction only returns 2 operands. Maybe this is a bug in `capstone`, but why do we have to rely on `capstone` for this? I mean, why do we have to check this https://github.com/angr/angr/blob/master/angr/analyses/disassembly.py#L216? We already have `op_str` to display everything don't we?

title: Merging / Veritesting: unexpected results
body:
Hi,

Consider this C function:
```
int foobar(int n) {
	int i;
	int sum = 0;
	for (i = 0; i < n; i++)
		sum = i;
	return sum;
}
```
Assembly:
```
00000000004004d6 <foobar>:
  4004d6:	55                   	push   %rbp
  4004d7:	48 89 e5             	mov    %rsp,%rbp
  4004da:	89 7d ec             	mov    %edi,-0x14(%rbp)
  4004dd:	c7 45 fc 00 00 00 00 	movl   $0x0,-0x4(%rbp)
  4004e4:	c7 45 f8 00 00 00 00 	movl   $0x0,-0x8(%rbp)
  4004eb:	eb 0a                	jmp    4004f7 <foobar+0x21>
  4004ed:	8b 45 f8             	mov    -0x8(%rbp),%eax
  4004f0:	89 45 fc             	mov    %eax,-0x4(%rbp)
  4004f3:	83 45 f8 01          	addl   $0x1,-0x8(%rbp)
  4004f7:	8b 45 f8             	mov    -0x8(%rbp),%eax
  4004fa:	3b 45 ec             	cmp    -0x14(%rbp),%eax
  4004fd:	7c ee                	jl     4004ed <foobar+0x17>
  4004ff:	8b 45 fc             	mov    -0x4(%rbp),%eax
  400502:	5d                   	pop    %rbp
  400503:	c3                   	retq
```
Where: 
```
foobar(0) => 0
foobar(1) => 0
foobar(2) => 1
foobar(3) => 2
```

When using the following angr script. I am not getting the expected result:
```
import angr
import claripy
import pdb

binary = 'merge'
project = angr.Project(binary, load_options={'auto_load_libs' : False})

start = 0x4004d6
end = 0x4004ff
state = project.factory.blank_state(addr=start, remove_options={angr.options.LAZY_SOLVES})

# constraints: 0 <= n <= 3
state.se.add(state.regs.edi <= 3)
state.se.add(state.regs.edi >= 0)

simgr = project.factory.simulation_manager(state, veritesting=True, veritesting_options={'boundaries': [end]})
simgr.explore(find=end)

assert len(simgr.found) == 1 and len(simgr.active) == 0

sol = simgr.found[0].se.any_n_int(simgr.found[0].memory.load(simgr.found[0].regs.rbp - 4, 4).reversed, 10)
sol_exp = [0, 1, 2]

print sol                           # output: [0]
print sol_exp                    # output: [0, 1, 2]
assert len(sol) == len(sol_exp) # Failure
```

Am I missing something here?

In a previous release of angr (5.6.x), when using some code similar to this, I was getting what I was expecting.

title: Bug in paged_memory.py when deep-copying pages for write
body:
Hi! While analyzing a binary, I ran into an issue of uninitialized memory access (which resulted in a new symbolic variable, which lead to a state explosion). I tracked down the issue to the management of page copies within the machine state. Even though new objects are created for the machine state and the memory, `SimPagedMemory.branch()` uses `new_pages = dict(self._pages)`, which creates shallow copies of the memory pages. This is fine for reads, but the pages need to be deep-copied for writes to avoid overlaps in machine states. As far as I understood, in `SimPagedMemory._get_page()`, if a write is requested, the class checks whether the page in question has been already deep-copied (the page number is listed in `SimPagedMemory._cowed`). If no, than a deep copy is created of the page, and the page number is added to `SimPagedMemory._cowed` to avoid further deep copies.

The VEX IR for the block which triggers the bug: [vex_ir.txt](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/1371297/vex_ir.txt). This IR has 6 successors (of which only 1 will be followed, the jump to `0x24dc0`), and the relevant instructions for the bug are the following:

```
   11 | if (t42) { PUT(ip) = 0x24db0; Ijk_Boring }
   <...>
   30 | if (t59) { PUT(ip) = 0x24db4; Ijk_Boring }
   <...>
   41 | STle(t68) = t51
   <...>
   58 | if (t90) { PUT(ip) = 0x24dc0; Ijk_Boring }
   <...>
   73 | if (t105) { PUT(ip) = 0x24dc4; Ijk_Boring }
   <...>
   77 | STle(t108) = t93
   <...>
   79 | STle(t110) = t95
   <...>
   81 | STle(t112) = t97
   <...>
   107 | if (t139) { PUT(ip) = 0x24dec; Ijk_Boring }
   NEXT: PUT(pc) = 0x00024dd4; Ijk_Boring
}
```

At lines 11 and 30, two successor states are generated from the original, their memory pages are shallow copies of the original's. At line 41, the first write in the block happens, so the original state makes a deep copy of the page in question and adds the page number to `SimPagedMemory._cowed`. At lines 58 and 73, two additional successor states are generated, with shallow copies to the original's memory pages. The bug is triggered at line 77: this write request references the same memory page that has already been deep copied at line 41. Because the page number has already been added to `SimPagedMemory._cowed`, no deep copy is created, the memory page is written to. Even though two successor states (lines 58 and 73) hold shallow copies of the that same memory page.

The issue should be solved by emptying `SimPagedMemory._cowed` whenever a copy is made of the `SimPagedMemory` instance. That should be in `SimPagedMemory.branch()`, but the current version of the code doesn't have this instruction.

title: Consider extra constraints when concretizing symbolic addresses
body: When concretizing symbolic memory addresses, we do the concretization first, without considering extra constraints that are added later to the state. Hence, the concretized address might conflict with newly added constraints. This is @badnack 's fix to the issue.

title: Mass fix raise
BlockNode can be missing in Function block list
body:
Hello, Apparently, in some code (code that has exceptions, or code that initializes hardware for example), we can encounter this kind of function call: ``` 00008008 : 8008: 4b08 ldr r3, [pc, #32] ; (802c ) 800a: 4809 ldr r0, [pc, #36] ; (8030 ) 800c: 4283 cmp r3, r0 800e: d20a bcs.n 8026 8010: 43da mvns r2, r3 8012: 2100 movs r1, #0 8014: 4402 add r2, r0 8016: f022 0203 bic.w r2, r2, #3 801a: 3204 adds r2, #4 801c: 441a add r2, r3 801e: f843 1b04 str.w r1, [r3], #4 8022: 4293 cmp r3, r2 8024: d1fb bne.n 801e 8026: f000 b83b b.w 80a0
``` Function `Main` is called in `ResetISR` using a `b` instruction instead of `bl`. Of course, VEX does not detect the call and `CFGAccurate` does not either. The problem might be just that there will not be any `Function` object for `Main`, and all basic blocks of `Main` will be in `Function` of `ResetISR`. But it can also be that a `Function` object does not contain any blocks. Here's an example: ``` 0000a220 : a220: 6041 str r1, [r0, #4] a222: 4770 bx lr ``` This function only has one single block. It is called from different places: - Here with a `b`, the function call is not detected ``` 0000969c : 969c: b538 push {r3, r4, r5, lr} 969e: 4605 mov r5, r0 96a0: 4c07 ldr r4, [pc, #28] ; (96c0 ) 96a2: 2200 movs r2, #0 96a4: 4620 mov r0, r4 96a6: 213d movs r1, #61 ; 0x3d 96a8: f000 fdae bl a208 96ac: 4629 mov r1, r5 96ae: 4620 mov r0, r4 96b0: f000 fdc4 bl a23c 96b4: 4620 mov r0, r4 96b6: e8bd 4038 ldmia.w sp!, {r3, r4, r5, lr} 96ba: 2103 movs r1, #3 96bc: f000 bdb0 b.w a220 ``` - Or here with a `bl`, but since the `BlockNode` is already in the `OSRAMWriteFirst` `Function` object, the `Function` `I2CMasterControl` is created but has no block. ``` 96ec: 2101 movs r1, #1 96ee: 4620 mov r0, r4 96f0: f000 fd96 bl a220 ``` So, I don't know what would be the best way to fix this. Adding more logic to reason about jumpkind? Or we can just add more test in `Function` class, like here. I guess this is a @ltfish issue. Please let me know what you think

title: fgets not setting file.pos correctly
body:
Hi,
It seems that the `fgets` simprocedure do not generates correct constraints concerning the `pos` field of `stdin` `SimFile`.

This is my test C file : 
```
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc, char** argv){
  char buff[16];
  memset(buff, 0, sizeof(buff));
  printf("Test fgets\n");
  fgets(buff, 16, stdin);
  for (int i=0; i<16; i++)
    printf("%02X ", buff[i]);
  printf("\n");
  return 0;
}
```

And this is my angr python code : 
```
import angr
b=angr.Project("./a.out", auto_load_libs=False)
sm=b.factory.simgr()
sm.step(until=lambda s: len(s.one_active.solver.constraints)!=0) # run until fgets simprocedure is executed and generate constraints
stdin=sm.one_active.posix.files[0]

min_pos=sm.one_active.solver.min_int(stdin.pos)
max_pos=sm.one_active.solver.max_int(stdin.pos)
print "stdin.pos is constrained to be between %d and %d"%(min_pos, max_pos)

newline_only_at_the_end=[stdin.all_bytes().get_byte(i)!='\n' for i in range(14)]+[stdin.all_bytes().get_byte(14)=='\n']
print sm.one_active.satisfiable(extra_constraints=newline_only_at_the_end)

newline_in_the_middle_not_at_the_end=[stdin.all_bytes().get_byte(i)!='\n' for i in range(0,7)+range(8,15)]+[stdin.all_bytes().get_byte(7)=='\n']
print sm.one_active.satisfiable(extra_constraints=newline_in_the_middle_not_at_the_end)

no_newline_at_all=[stdin.all_bytes().get_byte(i)!='\n' for i in range(0,15)]
print sm.one_active.satisfiable(extra_constraints=no_newline_at_all)
```
and the associated output : 
```
stdin.pos is constrained to be between 15 and 15
True
False
True
```
All three tests should give `True`as a result.

The symbolic `stdin.pos` should be able to take any of the following values : 
- 0, if `fgets` received EOF before any content
- between 1 and 14, if user entered between 0 and 13 characters + a newline
- 15, if the user entered 14 characters + a newline, or more than 15 characters

(for a reminder, this is the manpage for `fgets` : `fgets()  reads  in at most one less than size characters from stream and stores them into the buffer pointed to by s.  Reading stops after an EOF or a newline.  If a newline is read, it is stored into the buffer.  A terminating null byte ('\0') is stored after the last character in the buffer.`)

Is it normal ?
Thanks in advance

title: CFGFast: Fix a rare case leading to incorrect function-returning decisions.
body:
In CFGFast, we assume any function call should return to the same function
as its caller block as long as the callee returns. This holds in general,
but it does not hold in the following scenario during CFG recovery:

- We identify a function starting at address A. This function returns.
- We identify another function starting at address B. Unfortunately, many
  blocks of function B and function A overlap. This might be the result of
  multi-entry functions (in which case, both are correct), or function A
  starts at the alignment bytes ahead of function B (in which case,
  function B is the correct one, and function A should only contain the
  alignment bytes and a jumpout to the beginning of function B).
- At this time, all blocks other than the first block in function B belong
  to function A. Therefore, any transition going out of the first block of
  function B are outside transitions (they all transition to function A).

I noticed this issue a long time ago (probably before CGC), and added a
fix. However, I was only handling the cases when the first block of
function B jumps to its successors. The case where the first block calls
another function and then returns was not handled. This commit fixes this
issue.

Function 804a420 in the CGC binary CROMU_00071 can be used to test this
commit. It is included in Patcherex as a test case:
test_cfg.py:test_fullcfg_properties.

title: Missed loop by LoopFinder
body:
Hi, 
As discussed with @rhelmot on slack, our new `LoopFinder` (after the refactor) misses loops that contains function calls, e.g. `while (foo) { bar(); }`; while removing the call to `bar()` makes the loop to be detected again.

Here's an example:
ARM assembly code **with** function call inside loop:
```
  10426:   2364        movs    r3, #100    ; 0x64
  10428:   603b        str r3, [r7, #0]
  1042a:   e003        b.n 10434 <main+0x14>
  1042c:   2101        movs    r1, #1                       -> loop body node
  1042e:   6838        ldr r0, [r7, #0]
  10430:   f7ff ffe9   bl  10406 <foo>                     -> function call inside of loop
  10434:   687b        ldr r3, [r7, #4]                       -> loop entry
  10436:   1c5a        adds    r2, r3, #1
  10438:   607a        str r2, [r7, #4]
  1043a:   2b09        cmp r3, #9
  1043c:   d9f6        bls.n   1042c <main+0xc>
  1043e:   2300        movs    r3, #0
  10440:   4618        mov r0, r3
   ....
```
However, the loop is not detected: `len(loop_finder.loops) = 0`.

ARM assembly code **without** function call inside loop:
```
 275    10426:   2364        movs    r3, #100    ; 0x64
 276    10428:   603b        str r3, [r7, #0]
 277    1042a:   bf00        nop 
 278    1042c:   687b        ldr r3, [r7, #4]
 279    1042e:   1c5a        adds    r2, r3, #1
 280    10430:   607a        str r2, [r7, #4]
 281    10432:   2b09        cmp r3, #9
 282    10434:   d9fa        bls.n   1042c <main+0xc>
 283    10436:   2300        movs    r3, #0
 284    10438:   4618        mov r0, r3
```
`len(loop_finder.loops) = 1` this time.

title: SimProcedures do not return correctly if invoked with a jump instruction
body:
If a SimProcedure is invoked with a jump instruction (for example, as a result of a tail call optimization), for example:
```asm
jmpq   489820 <__libc_realloc>
```
the branch immediately deadends after running the SimProcedure instead of correctly continuing the program at the return address on the stack frame when the jump was invoked.

For reference (messages from @fish on the slack group):
> fish [1:38 PM] 
> @jake: it's very likely to be a bug. Can you please open an issue on GitHub?
>
> [1:39] 
> @jake: the solution is to fix the code in `SimProcedure.ret()` to manually load the return address from stack/the lr register instead of pre-calculating them at the call site (in this case, the jump site)
>
> [1:39] 
> I'm not aware of any easy workaround though, sorry :disappointed:

title: Possible bug in CFGFast
Edge missing in CFGAccurate without normalization for ARM
body:
Hi,

As the title says, here is some examples of it:

![issue1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23738463/27052837-67c9c524-4fbb-11e7-9800-f01fd28f7a9a.png)

The CFG block at 0x107e1 ends with an `bne` instruction, so it should have 2 exits: one at the address of the jump (0x10847) and one at the address of the next instruction of `bne` (0x1085b). However, the latter is missing.

![issue2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23738463/27052968-e73a572e-4fbb-11e7-8a3c-3ef98eff2913.png)

Here again, the block at 0x10843 should have one edge to the block at 0x10847 and another to the block at 0x1085b. The latter is missing.

I've printed out all edges of the CFG and these edges are not there either, so I don't think this is a display problem. I got this with `angr.analyses.CFGAccurate(normalize=False)`

As @ltfish's quick investigation, this may be due to VEX optimization, since passing `opt_level=0` solves the issue. Should we disable the cross-instruction optimization by default? But when a user wants the optimization level of 1, the issue may be raised again.

Thanks,

title: Pickle a Path?
body:
[solve.py.txt](https://github.com/angr/angr/files/1056377/solve.py.txt)

Guys,

I posted to the angr mailing list a few weeks back about not being able to pickle (to file) a path object in angr.  I was able to find a test case where it can be reproduced (the file I submitted named solve.py.txt).  This file should be placed in the angr-doc-master/examples/fauxware directory and run against the fauxware example file.  It is a slight mod on the original solve.py file that came in the fauxware directory.  This will demonstrate the problem.

So the problem is not that pickling the path object fails, but rather it succeeds, and then when pickle loads the object back in, it is a drastically larger size, and the path.history object is not the same as the path.history object that was originally pickled.  

This could just be an issue with how you have the angr/path_history.py PathHistory object setup (e.g. path_history._parent)...or there's a slight chance it's a bug in python's pickle.py.   I ran my tests using python 2.7.13

Thanks so much for your help.
Ejm

title: CFG misses blocks after function calls
body:
I have a small, statically linked ARM binary I would like to analyze, but angr's CFG is incomplete. The binary is at http://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/gergo/krempel/buggy_binary

I am interested in the CFG of the function located at address `0x8000`. Here is the script I use to build the CFG and dump this function's blocks:
```
import angr
proj = angr.Project('buggy_binary')
cfg = proj.analyses.CFGAccurate(starts=[0x8000], normalize=True)
f = cfg.functions[0x8000]
for i, b in enumerate(list(f.blocks)):
    print 'block', i
    b.pp()
```

It identifies two blocks in the function:
```
block 0
0x8014:	mov	r0, r1
0x8018:	ldr	r1, [sp, #0xc]
0x801c:	bl	#0x8028
block 1
0x8000:	push	{r4, lr}
0x8004:	mov	r1, r0
0x8008:	mov	r0, #0x50
0x800c:	ldr	r4, [sp, #8]
0x8010:	bl	#0x8030
```

The problem is that the function's third block is missing. For reference, here is objdump's disassembly:

```
00008000 <fn1>:
    8000:	e92d4010 	push	{r4, lr}
    8004:	e1a01000 	mov	r1, r0
    8008:	e3a00050 	mov	r0, #80	; 0x50
    800c:	e59d4008 	ldr	r4, [sp, #8]
    8010:	eb000006 	bl	8030 <__aeabi_idivmod>
    8014:	e1a00001 	mov	r0, r1
    8018:	e59d100c 	ldr	r1, [sp, #12]
    801c:	eb000001 	bl	8028 <__aeabi_idiv>
    8020:	e0200004 	eor	r0, r0, r4
    8024:	e8bd8010 	pop	{r4, pc}
```

angr's CFG does not include the block with the last two instructions.

```
import angr

binary = '/bin/ls' # we don't care for the binary, we just need an initial state
project = angr.Project(binary, load_options={'auto_load_libs' : False})

state = project.factory.entry_state(remove_options={simuvex.o.LAZY_SOLVES}, 
	add_options={simuvex.o.SYMBOLIC_WRITE_ADDRESSES}) # store range => 128, load range => 1024 

# an address which is in a valid region
start_addr = state.libc.heap_location 
state.libc.heap_location += 32 # mark 32 bytes as used 

# read/write 
assert state.se.any_int(state.memory.permissions(start_addr)) == 0x3
assert state.se.any_int(state.memory.permissions(start_addr + 1)) == 0x3
assert state.se.any_int(state.memory.permissions(start_addr + 2)) == 0x3

# initialize memory: 3 bytes starting at start_addr
state.memory.store(start_addr, claripy.BVV(0x0, 24), 3)

# a symbolic pointer that can be equal to [start_addr, start_addr + 1]
addr = claripy.BVS('addr', 64) 
state.se.add(addr >= start_addr)
state.se.add(addr <= start_addr + 1)
addrs = state.se.any_n_int(addr, 10)
assert len(addrs) == 2 and set(addrs) == set([start_addr, start_addr + 1])

val = 0xABCD

# symbolic store at addr
state.memory.store(addr, claripy.BVV(val, 16), 2)

# symbolic load at addr
res = state.memory.load(addr, 2)

# print res

res = state.se.any_n_int(res, 20) # up to 20 solutions
print "Obtained value(s): " + (' '.join(hex(x) for x in res))
print "Expected value:    " + hex(val)
 
assert len(res) == 1 and res[0] == val
```
Output:
```
Obtained value(s): 0xabcd 0xab00L
Expected value:    0xabcd
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "run.py", line 43, in <module>
    assert len(res) == 1 and res[0] == val
AssertionError

```
I do not understand why I don't get what I expect (i.e., `res` should be always equal to the value of `val`). What am I missing? Is it an actual bug?

title: Create fresh knowledge base for CFGAccurate
Fix/function returning checks
body:
There were various bugs in CFGAccurate. Involving how job entries were being created from function hints.

These fixes do permit CFGAccurate analysis to run using my test input, but please be sure no semantic issues are being ignored with these changes.

In particular, please check line 2437 where the original code expected the `action` variable to always be of type `SimActionData` but it would sometimes have another type in my test case (`SimActionOperation`).

title: Angr can't find path to address unless extra constraints are added to the initial state
body:
When running the following script on the [unbreakable](https://github.com/angr/angr-doc/blob/master/examples/google2016_unbreakable_0/unbreakable-enterprise-product-activation) challenge from GoogleCTF 2016, no path to the specified address is found, even though one definitely exists. Angr does not say anything about unconstrained paths, so I don't know any reason why no path would be found.

```
#!/usr/bin/env python2

from angr import *

input_size = 0x43
flag = claripy.BVS('flag', 8 * input_size)

p = Project('./unbreakable-enterprise-product-activation', load_options={'auto_load_libs': False})
state = p.factory.entry_state(args=[p.filename, flag])
pg = p.factory.path_group(state, veritesting=True)

state.libc.buf_symbolic_bytes = input_size + 1

for a, b in zip('CTF{', flag.chop(8)):
    state.se.add(ord(a) == b)

state.se.simplify()
logging.getLogger('angr.path_group').setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

pg.explore(find=(0x400830,), avoid=(0x400850,))
f = pg.found[0]

print f.state.se.any_str(flag)
```

If I add in some more constraints on the input buffer, then a path is found to that address:

```
#!/usr/bin/env python2

from angr import *

input_size = 0x43
flag = claripy.BVS('flag', 8 * input_size)

p = Project('./unbreakable-enterprise-product-activation', load_options={'auto_load_libs': False})
state = p.factory.entry_state(args=[p.filename, flag])
pg = p.factory.path_group(state, veritesting=True)

state.libc.buf_symbolic_bytes = input_size + 1

for a, b in zip('CTF{', flag.chop(8)):
    state.se.add(ord(a) == b)

# This for loop was added
for c in flag.chop(8):
    state.se.add(c > ord(' '))
    state.se.add(c < ord('~'))

state.se.simplify()
logging.getLogger('angr.path_group').setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

pg.explore(find=(0x400830,), avoid=(0x400850,))
f = pg.found[0]

print f.state.se.any_str(flag)
```

title: surveyors.Explorer and path_groups behave differently
body:
(This might be a better issue for simuvex, I'm not sure).

As far as I understand it, surveyors.Explorer and path_groups should behave the same, at least for simple challenges. For [defcamp r200](https://github.com/angr/angr-doc/blob/master/examples/defcamp_r200/r200) binary, they don't.

This code works with Explorer:

```
#!/usr/bin/env python2

from angr import *

logging.getLogger('angr.path_group').setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
logging.getLogger('angr.surveyors.explorer').setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

p = Project('./r200', load_options={'auto_load_libs': False})
state = p.factory.blank_state(addr=0x4008fa)#, remove_options={simuvex.s_options.LAZY_SOLVES})

e = p.surveyors.Explorer(find=(0x400936,), avoid=(0x400947,), enable_veritesting=True)
e.run()
f = e.found[0]

print f.state.se.any_str(f.state.posix.files[0].all_bytes())
```

#!/usr/bin/env python2

from angr import *

pg = p.factory.path_group(state, veritesting=True)
pg.explore(find=(0x400936,), avoid=(0x400947,))
f = pg.found[0]

print f.state.se.any_str(f.state.posix.files[0].all_bytes())
```

title: fail to handle linux syscall open when target binary is static build + angr BYPASS_UNSUPPORTED_SYSCALL enabled
body:
run this : 

```
cat > test.c << EOF
#include <fcntl.h>
int main()
{
    int fd = open("/test.c", O_RDONLY);
    close(fd);
    return 0;
}
EOF

gcc -o test test.c -static
mkdir angr-chroot

cat > test.py << EOF
import angr
import simuvex
p = angr.Project('test')
files = {}
state = p.factory.entry_state(fs=files, concrete_fs=True, chroot="angr-chroot/", add_options={"BYPASS_UNSUPPORTED_SYSCALL"})
pg = p.factory.path_group(state)
while 1:
  pg.step()
EOF

python test.py
```

and get this: 

```

ERROR   | 2016-05-26 22:39:56,664 | simuvex.procedures.syscalls | no syscall 63 for arch AMD64

  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/angr/path_group.py", line 341, in _one_step

  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/angr/path_group.py", line 289, in _one_path_step
    successors = a.step(**kwargs)

    self._make_sim_run()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/angr/path.py", line 533, in _make_sim_run
    self._run = self._project.factory.sim_run(self.state, **self._run_args)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/angr/factory.py", line 112, in sim_run
    return SimProcedures['syscalls']['handler'](state, addr=addr, ret_to=state.ip)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/simuvex-4.6.4.28-py2.7.egg/simuvex/s_procedure.py", line 67, in __init__
    r = run_func(*args, **self.kwargs)

the type of "name" is BVV SAO (not str).

title: posix not populating correctly
body:
Angr folk,

So I'm playing the TUCTF today and I was attempting to run angr against the "WoO2" challenge. Angr appeared to run correctly for the most part. It found some paths, and the output from `posix.dumps(1)` seemed correct. However, the corresponding input from `posix.dumps(0)` wasn't correct at all. This leads me to believe there's some issue with how that SimFile is being populated.

For reference, I didn't do anything fancy for the binary. Simply loaded it up and told it to explore all possibilities.

title: Handling of fake_rets is not consistent
body:
I'm not sure about the conception of fake_rets in the CFG, but I think I found an issue. To demonstrate this, here is the cfg for ais3_crackme:

This is the CFG generated by angr:
![ais3_cfg_full_bad](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/759365/14010866/94d881ee-f199-11e5-9722-0749683fdce1.png)

This is the CFG it should generate IMO:
![ais3_cfg_full_good](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/759365/14010867/94d94dc2-f199-11e5-8f9f-5aa73c9d5e63.png)

The difference is only that in the second graph the 0x40060e -> 0x400618 fake_ret edge is not missing.

This is the check in CFGAccurate, that "removes" that edge:

``` python
        # Let's check whether this address has been traced before.
        if pending_exit_tuple in self._nodes:
            node = self._nodes[pending_exit_tuple]
            if node in self.graph:
                pending_exit_addr = self._simrun_key_addr(pending_exit_tuple)
                # That block has been traced before. Let's forget about it
                l.debug("Target 0x%08x has been traced before. " + "Trying the next one...", pending_exit_addr)
                return None
```

Can you please validate this issue?
